hits._id: FACULTY INTERVIEWS TO BE HELD NEXT WEEK

_source.content:
The Education Ministry informed that the interviews to join new students for the national education faculties will commence from next week.
These interviews will be held to select students for 19 education science faculties spread across the island for 27 education courses.
The Education Ministry further said that 4069 students will be enrolled to the science faculties this time.

hits._id: Southern Provincial Education Minister expresses displeasure regarding Isurupaya

_source.content:
Southern Provincial Minister of Education Chandima Rasaputra states that he has questions regarding the activities of the Ministry of Education in Isurupaya.
 
He made this statement while speaking at a function held in Sangamitta College, Galle which was attended by the minister of education Bandula Gunawardena.
 
The Southern Provincial Minister of Education stated that the support provided by the Ministry of Education to solve the educational issue in the Southern Province is insufficient.
 
Following the address by the Southern Provincial Minister of Education, Minister of Education Bandula Gunawardena addressed the gathering.
 
Responding to the claims made by Minister Rasaputra, Minister Bandula Gunawardena stated that when taking decisions regarding national education, he does not give preference to a particular province.

hits._id: Mechanism to restructure school administration

_source.content: The Ministry of Education has decided to restructure the administration of education at the national and provincial level.Minister of Education Akila Viraj Kariyawasam stated that many issues have cropped up by having to monitor several schools through Zonal education offices.

hits._id: Grade one admissions from today

_source.content:
The admission for grade one students to government schools will commence today. Accordingly, the national event will be held at the Kotte President’s College from 8.30 this morning.
The Ministry of Education has introduced a new curriculum for grade one students from this year.
The Education Ministry in a statement noted, new guidelines pertaining teachers, teaching assistants and education officers have also been complied in line with a new education policy.
Deputy Minister of Education V.S. Radhakrishnan and Education Ministry Secretary W.M. Bandusena will be participating at the event.

hits._id: Bandula visits the office of his former ministry

_source.content: Former education minister Bandula Gunawardana met current Minister of Education Akila Viraj Kariyawasam at the latter’s office today. The former minister visited minister Kariyawasam to discuss certain shortcomings of the Mahinda Rajapaksa Vidyalaya in Homagama. Later Minister Kariyawasam has instructed his officials to resolve the problems of the school with immediate effect. The Education Ministry stated in its communiqué that the former minister and the current minister of Education have discussed the progressive aspects of the ongoing education reforms.

hits._id: Disciplinary action against former Principal of Southlands College - Galle

_source.content:
The Education Ministry says that attention has been drawn on taking disciplinary action in the near future with regard to the activities of former principal of Galle Southlands College Shanthi Seneviratne.
Issuing a communiqué the Education Ministry says the former principal had prevented Sandhya Pathiranawasam who had been appointed and dispatched as the new principal from assuming her duties as well as obstructed the performance of duties of the Education Director who had come to inquire about the problem.  
In the communiqué it said that the provincial education director as well as the Education Ministry had been informed about it.
On February 12th this year, former principal of Southlands College Shanthi Seneviratne had sent a letter to the Education Ministry requesting for a transfer to the Southern Provincial Education Department.
Accordingly the Education Ministry Secretary had transferred her to the Southern Province Education Department on March 17th with the Public Services Commission approval.
The communiqué further says that it is regrettable that the former principal of Southlands College has taken action refusing to accept the transfer when it had been made after taking her request into consideration.  
Our news team inquired from Southern Province Education Director Jayatissa Block with regard to the problem prevalent at the Southlands College - Galle.
The Education Director said that the former principal had committed a serious offence by acting without being submissive to the Education Minister’s order.

hits._id: A change in the University education system.

_source.content:
The higher education Ministry has decided to make a change to the teaching method in Universities.
 
Secretary of the Higher education Ministry Sunil Jayantha Nawarathna stated that a student centered education system will be initiated instead of a teacher centered education system.
 
Speaking further the secretary stated that this new method is initiated in several universities as at present.

hits._id: Guinness record attempt : CP Education Secretary in trouble

_source.content:
Central Province Governor Niluka Ekanayake says Central Province Education Secretary should be held responsible for allowing 250 schoolchildren to be used for a Guinness world record attempt in Kandy recently.
In this incident, 250 schoolchildren were used to hold the fall of an 'osariya' - a traditional Kandyan sari. A special investigation was held under the patronage of the Governor this morning (25). 
Central Province's Education Director, Acting Education Director of Katugastota, Principal of Alawathugoda Sarath Ekanayake Primary School, and Provincial Assistant Education Secretary were in the meeting.
However, Central Province's Education Secretary did not attend the meeting. Although the Governor allowed the media to cover the meeting, the education officials opposed the move.
No body spoke to the media even after the event. However, the Governor said the investigations will be continued further.
The Ministry of Education and National Child Protection Authority have also investigating the incident.

hits._id: Badulla principal makes 7-hour statement at SLHRC

_source.content:
The principal of Badulla Girls’ School, R. Bhavani who was allegedly forced by the Uva Chief Minister to kneel before him has made a 7-hour statement to the Sri Lanka Human Rights Commission today (Jan. 25).
At the same time, Uva Education Secretary, Sandhya Ambanwala, and 6 others were also summoned before the Commission to record statements with regard to the incident.
Accordingly, Provincial Education Secretary, Provincial Education Director, Zonal Education Director and a representative of the Badulla OIC have appeared before Commission today.
Lanka Teachers' Association had complained to the Sri Lanka Human Rights Commission about the incident.
Meanwhile, our correspondent said that the staff of the Badulla Tamil Girls’ School protested when the newly appointed Provincial Tamil Education Minister, Senthil Thondaman visited the school today.
Meanwhile, Uva Provincial Governor, M.P. Jayasinghe told our news team that action will be taken against 3 officials including Uva Provincial Education Secretary, Sandhya Ambanwala, and Provincial Education Director when he receives the investigation report.

hits._id: NOTICE TO PARENTS FROM EDUCATION MINISTRY

Issuing a statement state education Minister V. Radhakrishnan said if any such instances of charging fees without receipts occur, to notify the nearest zonal education office or provincial office without delay.
The education ministry received many complaints recently over schools charging money while enrolling children.

hits._id: Lanka Teachers Association President interdicted.

_source.content:
Lanka Teachers Association President and teacher of Tissawewa Devanam Piyatissa Vidyalaya in Anuradhapura Priyantha Fernando has been interdicted with effect from today.
 
Provincial Education Secretary R.K. Premasiri said that Fernando was interdicted after an inquiry against him found that he had gone abroad without informing the Provincial Education Ministry beforehand.
 
When a teacher wants to go abroad, he or she should obtain prior approval from the Education Ministry.
 
Provincial Education Secretary R.K. Premasiri said that Lanka Teachers Association President Priyantha Fernando has not informed  his superiors before he visited India in 2009.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
However Lanka Teachers Association Secretary Joseph Starlin said that the interdiction of his Association President Fernando is a conspiracy against exposing frauds and corruption by the North Central Provincial Education Ministry.

hits._id: Ministry of Education and Provincial Ministry of Education clash

_source.content:
A tense situation occurred between the Ministry of Education and Provincial Ministers of Education, following a special meeting held in Kandy between the Provincial Ministers and Chief Ministers today.
Accordingly, the Provincial Education Ministers and the Chief Ministers have decided not to let their officials from provincial ministries participate in the meetings convened by the Ministry of Education.
Provincial education ministers representing six provinces participated in the meeting held in Kandy, including representatives from Northern, Western and Sabaragamu provinces.
Chief Minister of Central Province Sarath Ekanayake voiced his strong objection against the manner in which certain ministries act, by exceeding the powers of the relevant provincial councils.
When our news team enquired from the Minister of Education Akila Viraj Kariyawasam with regard to the matter, he had this to say.

He stressed that it is imperative to follow proper protocols and procedures under the country’s constitution during a period when the government is adhering to good governance.

hits._id: A New Education System Will Be Introduced – PM

_source.content:
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe says a new education system will be introduced in the near future.
Speaking at an event held in Colombo last evening, Premier Wickremesinghe said the present government hopes to develop education costs through the growth of the country’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
He said the country’s development relies on the education system in the island.
The Prime Minister said the public was promised of a 6 per cent allocation for education from the Gross Domestic product when President Maithripala Sirisena was elected as the new President.
Accordingly, he said the economy should be further developed in order to keep to the government’s promise.

_source.content:
GMOA doctors continue to stage a protest at the Mministry of Education premises demanding that their children be granted admission into popular schools.
The Government doctors who went to Isurupaya last afternoon requesting a meeting with the Minister of Education, chose to stage an overnight protest at the Education Ministry premises.
At this time about 200 Government doctors remained at the premises.
However, GMOA Central Committee Member Dr. Prasad Ranaveera said that action had been taken to disconnect electricity in the ministry of education auditorium where the doctors spent the night.

It was stated that the GMOA was insisting that the Ministry grant their children admission to the most popular schools in the capital and suburbs.  
Expressing his views with regard to this Education Minister Akila Viraj Kariyawasam said that the demand being made by the GMOA was unfair.
Meanwhile the GMOA will stage token strikes from 8 a.m. to 12 noon today in hospitals in the Kurunegala, Kandy and Matara districts.

Meanwhile the principal of the school has temporarily been transferred to Piliyandala Zonal Education Office. Western Province Education Secretary Daya Rathgama said that a special investigation would be held with regard to this abuse incident.

The gazette notification to admit students into the National College of Education will be issues on 09 this month, the Ministry of Education stated.

hits._id: Badulla principal : Seven summoned by SLHRC

_source.content:
Following a notice issued with regard to the incident where the principal of a Tamil Girls’ School in Badulla was allegedly forced to kneel by the Chief Minister Chamara Sampath Dassanayake, 7 individuals including the Uva Province Education Secretary Sandya Ambanwala are to appear before the Sri Lanka Human Rights Commission today (Jan. 25).
 
The provincial education secretary, provincial education director, zonal education director, OIC of the Badulla police, two journalists as well as a worker of the Uva Provincial council were issued notices.
 
A committee, headed by the Uva Provincial Secretary has been appointed to investigate the incident.
 
The committee was appointed by the Uva Governor M. P. Jayasinghe.
 
The Governor noted that the committee was appointed in accordance with the complaints received by the teacher associations.
 
Meanwhile, Minister Palani Digambaram said that as Sendil Thondaman is considered by many as being a racist, appointing him as the Provincial Tamil Education Minister is not a solution.
 
He said this at a media briefing held in Colombo yesterday.

hits._id: False allegations cannot prevent the government’s journey; President.-Video

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapaksa has stressed that false allegations cannot prevent the government’s journey as the government is built on the people’s trust.He said that false allegations have a short lifespan so the government would not waste time replying to them.He was speaking at the inaugural ceremony to set up 250 Technical Education Units under the project to set up one thousand Mahindodaya Schools throughout the country held at the Lumbini Vidyalaya in Colombo today.Speaking further at the ceremony the President said that the government would systematically fulfill its duty for education and will create an education system that will suite the nation.Meanwhile foundation stones were laid to build Mahindodaya Technical Education Units in the nine Provinces.Having opened the Technical Education Unit of Thurston College, President Rajapaksa joined an inspection tour in the school premises and enquired from students of their progress.The President’s Media Unit stated that later the President also opened the new indoor stadium of the school.Several parliamentarians including Colombo District MP R. Dumindha Silva also participated in the event

hits._id: Medical education standards : Crucial discussion planned

_source.content:
A decisive discussion on minimum standards of medical education will be held this week.
Health Minister Dr. Rajitha Senarathna while confirming it said that the Gazette on standards of medical education will also be issued soon.
He added a meeting in this regard will be held on 27th of this month.
However, the Government Medical Officers' Association accuses that the assurance given by the Health Minister to Gazette minimum standards for medical education has limited to a mere statement.
They also said attempts are being made by the Health Minister to transfer the powers of Sri Lanka Medical Council to another entity.
The GMOA Central Committee member, Dr. Prasad Colombage said that the Health Minister is trying to hoodwink all by saying that it will be done to streamline Sri Lanka's medical education.

hits._id: 3,000 Advanced Level teachers to be transferred from tomorrow

_source.content:
Ministry of Education has decided to transfer teachers who have served more than 10 years at a National School.
This will be implemented in line with the National Teacher Transfer Policy, which was not implemented for years.
The Education Ministry says there are 12,000 teachers at National Schools who have served more than 10 years.
Out of them, 3000 teachers in advanced level classes of National Schools will be transferred starting from tomorrow.
The relevant documents will be handed over to respective principals tomorrow, the Education Ministry said.

hits._id: Tense situation in Parliament over education

_source.content:
Heated arguments over the budgetary allocations for the Education Ministry took place in parliament today as well.
Parliament convened today under the patronage of Speaker Karu Jayasuriya.
Prior to the budget debate MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake made a statement regarding the budgetary allocation of 5.4 percent from the GDP for the education sector.
However the opposition claimed that the statistics announced by the Finance Minister is not tangible and transparent.
Joining the argument, MP Bandula Gunawardana said that no government can bear the allocation given for education sector by the budget 2016.

hits._id: Teachers & Principals Collective engages in a protest

_source.content: The Teachers & Principals Collective and the Parents Collective engaged in a protest together in front of Ministry of Education today against students who have obtained high marks for the year 5 scholarship examination not being granted admission to popular schools.The convenor of the Teachers & Principals Collective, Joseph Stalin, who spoke during the protest, requested the education authorities to allow those students who obtained high marks compared to last year to be allowed admission to popular schools.However, a group of representatives from the Teachers & Principals Collective have entered the Ministry of Education to engage in discussions.

hits._id: No use of talking over the allocation for education; Minister Bandula says in Parliament

hits._id: State Minister’s protest to NPC Education Minister who said ‘no’ for hoisting the National Flag

hits._id: An investigation by education Ministry about private schools that did not begin the 2nd term.

hits._id: Principals granted authority to close schools in areas affected by adverse weather

_source.content: The Minister of Education has granted authority to the principals of schools in areas affected by the inclement weather, to decide whether schools should be held or not.The Ministry of Education announced that principals have been granted permission to decide if schools should be held or not considering the risk prevailing in the area around the school.Furthermore, Minister of Education, Akila Viraj Kariyawasam has issued directives to authorities to provide a report immediately on school children affected by the adverse weather conditions.The Ministry of Education stated that the report is required to provide text books, uniforms and other necessary materials to such students.Meanwhile, Chief Ministers have stated that schools in areas affected by the Disaster situation in Western and Southern provinces will be closed tomorrow due to the prevailing disaster situation.The Ministry of Education of the Sabaragamuwa Province has also decided that schools in Ratnapura and Niwithigala will be closed tomorrow.Meanwhile, the Media Division of University of Kelaniya noted that its external degree examinations which were scheduled to be held on the 4th of June, have been postponed until further notice.

hits._id: EDUCATION MINISTRY REPLIES TO CHARGES OVER NOT GIVING ACCESS TO SCHOOL HALL

_source.content:
The Education Ministry has clarified its position on charges made about not granting access to hold a public speech at Mahawa Wijayaba College main hall.
Issuing a statement the Education Department said that the principal was questioned on this incident.
The principal has stated that a group of people have tried to use the school hall for a political agenda which resulted in not granting access to proceed with the meeting.
Education Ministry went on to say that any organization booking the hall must carry out only the stated purpose for which the school hall is booked.
The Mahawa Wijayaba College principal has forwarded a letter to secretary of Education Ministry citing that in such circumstances a state owned school building cannot be given over for political activities.

hits._id: New circular with regard to school sports competitions.

_source.content:
The Education Ministry has decided to issue a new circular with regard to school children participating in sports competitions.
Education Minister Bandula Gunawardhana said that this step was taken since reports had been made of several unfortunate incidents connected with children’s participation in sports competitions.
Participating at a discussion held at the Education Ministry yesterday with regard to releasing a new circular, said that a circular with regard to the participation of school children in sports competitions had already been released.
However on this occasion the Minister said that there was a question as to whether all schools followed that circular.

			   
			   		
	
			   
Speaking further he also had this to say...

			   
			   		
	
			   
President Mahinda Rajapakse today issued instructions to the Ministry of Education to subject students to a physical test prior to them entering into athletic events.

hits._id: Number of subjects for O/L to be reduced

A Ministry spokesperson said that relevant recommendations have been submitted by the National Education Institute.
The main subjects would be Religion, Language, Mathematics, Science, English and History & Social studies.

hits._id: New act within 2 months to safeguard higher education standards

Minister of Higher Education and Highways Lakshman Kiriella says that a new Act will be presented before parliament within the next two months with the objective of standardizing private universities.
The Minister made the statement at a function held at the Advanced Technology Education Institute in Kandy yesterday.

hits._id: Grade one admission for next year on January 11

hits._id: Video: MP R Dumindha Silva intervenes to solve the Gothatuwa Maha Vidyalaya issue

_source.content: Students of Kolonnawa- Gothatuwa Maha Vidyalaya and the parents request the education officials to develop the school to a secondary school.A discussion was held with this regard under the patronage of Colombo district Parliamentarian R Dumindha Silva at Gothatuwa Kande Viharaya.Gothatuwa Maha Vidyalaya was established 50 years ago, however during last year education activities deteriorated and classes were limited to grade 5.According to a decision taken by the Education department students of this college are transferred to Kollonnawa Olcott College after grade 5.Parents of the students stated that its a hindrance to them.Subsequently, to solve the issue a discussion was held under the patronage of MP R Dumindha Silva and the parents at the Gothatuwa Kande Viharaya.MP R Dumindha Silva stated that the matter will be discussed with the education Minister and a solution will be given on Monday.

hits._id: Dengue Awareness Programme To Be Conducted In Schools Island Wide

_source.content:
The Education Ministry states that the instructions have been given to island wide government schools to conduct a workshop on eradicating Dengue menace.
The schools have been instructed in this manner after discussions held with the Education State Minister, Nuwara Eliya District Parliamentarian V. Radhakrishnan, and the Education Ministry states.

hits._id: Principal of Kingswood College interdicted

_source.content:
The Principal of Kingswood College, Kandy has been interdicted for violating money regulations, the Ministry of Education stated.

hits._id: Deputy Minister Nandimithara sends special letter to President

Speaking to our news team deputy Minister of Higher Education Nandimithra Ekanayeke categorically denied these allegations.

hits._id: Video :Update : There are no Education Commission recommendations for abolishing the scholarship, say teacher unions

_source.content: The Teacher Unions say that the National Education Commission has not submitted recommendations for abolishing the Scholarship Examination. Lanka Teachers’ Union general secretary Joseph Stalin said that his union met the NEC officials yesterday. The Teacher Union general secretary said that at the meeting it came to light the NEC had not submitted recommendations with regard to abolishing the scholarship examination.However Education Minister Bandula Gunawardhana had earlier said that the NEC had submitted recommendations for abolishing the grade 5 scholarship examination by 2016.Update : Tuesday, 31 December 2013 - 8:24---------------------------------------------------------------Minister Bandula ready for a dialogue over Year-5 Scholarship ExaminationMonday, 30 December 2013 - 21:27The National Education Commission has proposed that the year-5 scholarship examination should only be held in 2014 and 2015.According to Commission recommendations, 1000 fully fledged Mahindodaya Secondary Schools to be introduced by 2016 covering all Divisional Secretariats in the country.The Commission has also recommended that the Year-5 scholarship examination should limit to one hour and one question paper to be held at the end of the year.Education Minister Bandula Gunawardana recently said that year-5 scholarship examination would be transformed to testing general knowledge of students.Main political parties as well as education unionists raised objections against the Minister’s decision to do away with the examination.The JHU stated in a media communiqué today that the year-5 scholarship examination should not be abolished merely for its shortcomings.The party stated that the Year-5 scholarship examination and the GCE Advance Level examination are the only 2 options that open a golden gate to higher education in this country and claimed that the Education Minister’s decision would close these 2 golden gates for the ordinary man’s talented children.The JHU therefore proposed to overcome the current shortcomings of the examination and preserve it for the benefit of the ordinary students.Meanwhile a media conference was held at the Education Ministry today to explain the recommendations made by the National Education Commission on the Year-5 scholarship examination.Addressing the media, Minister Bandula Gunawardana invited Provincial Councilor Udaya Gammanpila for a dialogue over the issue.When our news team contacted Provincial councilor Udaya Gammanpila, he said that he would accept the Education Minister’s invitation.

hits._id: Colombo Fort Magistrate issues summons on Sanjeeva Bandara

hits._id: Guinness record: Akila also calls for a report

_source.content:
Education Minister Akila Viraj Kariyawasam has also called for a report on the incident where schoolgirls had been used to display a wedding saree fall, during an attempted Guinness record in Kandy yesterday (21).
The Education Minister has issued a directive to the Ministry Secretary to look into the incident and present a report to him.
The fall was around 3km long and schoolgirls of Alawathugoda Primary School lined up along the Kandy-Gannoruwa Road displaying it.
However, that school does not come under the purview of the Ministry of Education and it is coming under the Central Provincial Council.
The Education Ministry in a statement says that the circulars which are issued by it as a line Ministry, are valid for all the schools in the country.
Earlier, the National Child Protection Authority also said that they are launching an investigation into the incident.
It was reported that around 250 schoolgirls had been used for the purpose.

hits._id: Circular issued by Education Ministry prohibiting use of children in protests

_source.content:
The Education Ministry has issued a circular prohibiting use of school children in protests during school hours and entry of outsiders to school premises.
This step was taken after receiving many complaints from parents and taking into consideration other facts revealed.
Certain persons and organized groups are working towards spreading information and creating extremist opinions among school children against government policies and plans, according to information received by the Education Ministry.
The circular also bans holding any meetings or discussions inside school premises without prior special permission obtained from education ministry or provincial educational secretaries or provincial directors.
The circular emphasized that school principals will be held personally responsible for chaotic situations created by not adhering to these instructions.

The Kaduwela Magistrate issued a ruling today ordering all GMOA members to leave the Education Ministry premises after they had spent the night in the auditorium staging a protest. 
Kaduwela Magistrate Dhammika Hemapala issued this order after considering a motion filed by the Ministry of Education today. 
Over 200 GMOA members occupied the auditorium of the Ministry yesterday demanding a meeting with the subject minister.
The issue was regarding their children being granted admission to popular schools.
The doctors spent last night inside the Education Ministry premises.  However, the protesting doctors left the Education Ministry premises after the Court order was issued this morning.

Functions of government hospitals in the districts of Kurunegala, Kandy, and Matara were disrupted from 8 o’clock in the morning to 12 noon due to the token strikes launched by the GMOA.
At the same time, Health Minister Rajitha Senarathna has called an emergency meeting this afternoon over the GMOA’s Year-one children’s admission issue.
GMOA stated that its executive committee will take the course of action after the meeting with the subject minister this afternoon.

hits._id: University lecturers urge to establish Public Commission on education

_source.content:
The university lecturers are urging the authorities to establish a public commission considering the issues faced by the education sector in the country.
 
They have made this request in an open letter signed by 66 university academics.
 
They also reject the solutions proposed by the government to solve the SAITM issue and demand to suspend all the initiatives taken to privatize school and higher education.
The academics said that such a privatized system of higher education can only be sustained with state subsidies, student loans, and other ‘public-private partnerships.’
They added that although these initiatives have failed elsewhere, the government supports such outdated policies, including the current set of proposals on SAITM, to appease private interests.

hits._id: Ministers and faculty deans present proposals on SAITM; Student Admissions suspended for 6 months

_source.content:
The Deans from eight state medical faculties had discussions with the Minister of Higher Education Lakshman Kiriella, Deputy Minister Mohan Lal Grero and officials at the University Grants Commission regarding SAITM.  They agreed to submit several proposals to the administration of the private medical college in Malabe.
During the next six months, the ministry of Higher Education and Highways, University Grants Commission, the SLMC and other stake holders will jointly develop an operational procedure applicable to non-state medical education.
Following yesterday’s discussion, the two parties also agreed to propose to the administration of SAITM to suspend further admission of medical students for a period of six months until the periodic review of the medical degree programme is conducted by the ministry of Higher Education.
They had also proposed that students from SAITM who have passed the final MBBS examination must undergo a further clinical training.
This would require one month training dedicated to the areas of surgery, medicine, obstetrics and gynecology and paediatrics, at a state hospital.
At the conclusion of this period, the students must pass a licensing examination conducted by the SLMC.

Pakistan and Sri Lanka will sign four agreements related to foreign service training, education, and tourism during the President’s visit.

hits._id: Gazette Notification Released

_source.content:
Government institutions and subjects belonging to 48 ministries were gazetted today.
The Cabinet was sworn in on 4th and 9th of this month.
Although there are 48 cabinet ministers, information of 50 ministries are included in the gazette released today.
A new ministry has been introduced as National Integrity and Reforms.
At the same time, Justice Ministry is joined with Buddhasasana Ministry.
However Justice and Buddhasasana functions under one minister.
Security, Mahaweli Development and Environment still remain under the president’s purview but 22 institutions, which functioned under the Prime Minister earlier, have been moved to other ministries.
At the same time, two new institutions - National Salary Commission and National Center for Leadership Development – have been taken under the Prime Minister. The Central Bank functions under the Prime Minster as usual.
The 35 institutions which functioned under the Finance Ministry earlier have been reduced to 26. Some of the removed institutions are: State Banks, National Salary Commission, Import and Export Department and Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation.
Meanwhile Sri Lanka Thriposha Company Limited has been added to the Health Ministry.
20 institutions have been added to the Education Ministry this time. Earlier 12 institutions only came under the purview of the Education Ministry.  However National Education Commission has been removed from the Education Ministry.  Among the newly added institutions are: Archaeological Department, Central Cultural Fund, National Art Council and Department of National Archives.

hits._id: Government To Set Up University For Police

_source.content:
Government will set up a university for the Police and Criminal Justice similar to that of the Deakin University in Melbourne, Australia, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe said recently.
“We must not to look at the University Structure of Sri Lanka or UK when we design the structure of the proposed Police and Criminal Justice University but look at the structure of Deakin University in Melbourne, Australia which has a deputy Vice Chancellor for Academic Development and Staff programme,” the Prime Minister said.
Prime Minister Wickremesinghe was addressing the International Industrial Mathematics Conference 2016, organized by the Department of Mathematics, University of Sri Jayawardenapura held at Fingara Town and Country Club, Rattanapitiya, Boralesgamuwa.
The Prime Minister also asserted on the need to change the university structure.
“This is an ideal time to bring structural reforms to the country's higher education especially make changes in the ideology and structure of Sri Lanka's universities since we have a multi-party state,” the Prime Minister said.
The Premier also said that it was hard to bring reforms to the country's university education due to the interference of political parties with ideologies.
“Under the leadership of President Maithripala Sirisena, now we have a multi-party state. So this is an ideal opportunity for us to work for the country's development. So I invite university academics and other relevant authorities to join hands to bring reforms to country's university education by making the maximum use of this opportunity,” the Premier said.
He also emphasized the necessity of establishing language labs in universities.
The Prime Minister said the government has already paid attention towards the uplift of the country's school education system and added that the government has also taken measures to preserve the country's history by establishing a separate institution on history.

views to the media.University teachers say the committee rejected certain verbal recommendations sent by the Minister through Dr. Abeyrathna Bandara.They also said that they received a fax message from the Minister asking them to consider the change of a particular proposed answer in the paper.However Education Minister Bandula Gunawardana said in parliament on the 24th of April that he was not hits._id: Govt. announces abolition of SAITM

_source.content: The Department of Government Information says that on 30th of December 2017, the Government signed a Memorandum of Understanding with SAITM and Sri Lanka Institute of Information Technology (SLIIT). According to this MoU, with the abolition of SAITM, SLIIT, a leading non-state, not-for-profit degree awarding institute, will establish the new sunset and sunrise institutions, under the guidance of the Government that will take over ownership and management of SAITM’s assets, liabilities, staff and students. The statement added that subject to the approval of the Attorney General’s Department, this MoU will be converted into a legal agreement.This solution resolves both concerns raised by various groups, it added. They are: * SAITM does not meet Sri Lanka’s high standards for medical education* SAITM’s profit motive will pervert the goal of creating good doctors* Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC), which establishes and maintains national standards for the medical profession, proposed a thorough set of Minimum Standards for Medical Education and Training that was accepted by the Cabinet with minor amendments on 13.12.2017 * This filled a major void in ensuring high standards of medical education* Medical education and training of the ‘sunset’ institution will be approved by the SLMC in accordance with the Minimum Standards. The SLMC will specify further measures (clinical training and assessment in state hospitals) necessary for students who have received degrees from SAITM, to meet these Standards and thereby gain Provisional Registration* SLMC will grant fresh approval for the ‘sunrise’ institution upon its meeting Minimum Standards, through an institutional review and site visits as per their mandate and standard practice for this purpose* The ‘sunset’ and ‘sunrise’ institutions will not operate for profit. The ‘sunrise’ institution will be a company limited by guarantee that charges fees, but re-invests any excess income over expenditure in the institution, including in the provision of scholarships based on financial need. SLIIT is an ideal partner in this effort, with two decades of experience in providing high-quality, not-for-profit higher education* Thus this practical and equitable solution recognizes, addresses, and resolves the concerns expressed against SAITM, and is fully compliant with the Communiqué issued by the President on 29.10.2017* Additionally, the Neville Fernando Teaching Hospital will be transferred to the Ministry of Health, allowing the State medical sector to gain a Rs. 3.2 billion assets at no cost to the StateThe Department of Government Information said that the solution has the unanimous approval of the 9-member Committee, which was Chaired by Dr. Harsha de Silva, Deputy Minister of National Policies and Economic Affairs.

hits._id: Sri Lanka ranked 5th amongst countries that dispose garbage into the sea

_source.content:
Sri Lanka has been ranked fifth among countries that dispose of plastic and solid waste into the sea. 
The Environment and Nature Education Centre pointed out that this has been revealed in research carried out in 192 countries, by the International Business Times.
China topped the list, Indonesia ranked second while the Philippines took the number three spot.
According to the International Business Times, over 13 million tons of plastic and solid waste is being disposed of into the sea around the world. 
Over 80 percent of such waste is being disposed by the first 20 countries alone.
However the Environment and Nature Education Center states that this situation could worsen and be increased by the year of 2025.
One of the main reasons to that projected effect maybe the establishment of proposed Colombo Port City project.
National Coordinator of the organization Vekandawala Rahula Thera said the lack of proper waste management systems is the main reason for the increased disposing of waste into the sea.

hits._id: SAITM to be abolished

_source.content: The government has decided to abolish SAITM which is owned by Dr Neville Fernando and convert it to a not-for-profit institute.Issuing a communique, the Department of Government Information said it will be functioned under the Ministry of Higher Education and University Grants Commission.Accordingly, new enrollments to SAITM will be stopped and new enrollments will be made only after the new entity is established which will have minimum standards required for medical education.The Presidential Committee to resolve issues related to the faculty of medicine of SAITM, after considering the recommendations made by numerous stakeholders, has presented eight proposals to arrive at a permanent solution that is reasonable to all stakeholders and is in line with the government policy. First Proposal:Abolishing the medical faculty of SAITM. This shall be done in a manner legally acceptable to the current shareholders, lending institutions and the new entity interested in taking over all operations and management of the medical faculty of SAITM on a not-for-profit basis, thus ending the ownership and management structure of the medical faculty of SAITM. The profit-oriented entity owned and managed by Dr Neville Fernando and family would thereby cease to exist. Second Proposal:By an agreement reached by the above parties, the assets, liabilities, staff and students of SAITM medical faculty shall be transferred to a non-state, not-for-profit making degree awarding entity that will comply with the minimum standards of medical education and training. Third Proposal: The Government has consulted several already established non-state, not-for-profit entities with the objective of establishing the proposed not-for-profit entity for this purpose. Detailed discussions in this regard with interested parties shall start very soon. Fourth Proposal:The new entity shall recognize all students currently enrolled at SAITM medical faculty who possess the required entry qualifications. Opportunity will be afforded to these students to continue medical education in the proposed new institution. Fifth Proposal:Issues in respect of former students who have completed their degree course at SAITM medical faculty should be addressed on the advice of the Sri Lanka Medical Council, based on the determination of the Supreme Court case filed on the same. Arrangements shall be made for the said students who have completed the degree at SAITM medical faculty to undergo clinical training at recommended government hospitals. Sixth Proposal:Admission of medical students to SAITM medical faculty has been suspended by the letter issued by the Secretary to the Ministry of Higher Education on the 15th of September 2017. This suspension will continue to be in effect. Accordingly, all new admissions shall be made to the new entity, when only complying with the minimum standards of medical education and training. The Government shall cooperate on all endeavours to make available, through financial institutions, subsidized student loan schemes to eligible students from low-income families to meet the cost of tuition and fees. Seventh Proposal:Current shareholders of SAITM medical faculty shall not participate in the ownership or management of the new entity. The cooperation of Dr Neville Fernando and family is extremely important in this regard. Eighth Proposal:The Ministry of Health shall gazette and place before Parliament the agreed minimum standards for medical education and training based on the draft submitted by the Sri Lanka Medical Council, upon conclusion of discussions with the SLMC, the Hon. Attorney General and other relevant stakeholders. This task must be mandatorily completed within one month from today. The communiqué further noted that a committee of high-level officials will be appointed to implement the proposed measures and that the entire process should be completed mandatorily by the end of this year.

The Coordinating secretary to the Prime Minister Ranil Wickremasinghe and Former Minister Suranimala Rajapaksha passed away this morning at the aged of 68 (March 14).
Mr. Rajapaksha, born in 1949, was first elected to the Parliament of Sri Lanka in 1994 and he was the Minister of School Education from 2001 to 2004. Being member of the UNP, he was appointed as the Coordinating secretary to the Prime Minister Wickremasinghe on 27 January 2015.

hits._id: SLMC boycotts Harsha de Silva Committee meeting

_source.content:
The Sri Lanka Medical Council has decided to boycott today’s meeting scheduled to take place with the Committee headed by Dr. Harsha de Silva, which was appointed to look into the SAITM issue.
A senior official of the SLMC stated that the Harsha de Silva Committee Report has included certain matters that the SLMC did not agree with.
He said their concerns were conveyed during a meeting they had on 6th of September. In protest of that move, SLMC has decided to boycott today’s meeting.
The senior official also said that the SLMC sent several recommendations in writing to the Committee, to be considered.
SLMC recommends:
* New enrolments to SAITM be stopped
* Not to share ‘minimum standards of medical profession’ with other bodies
* Not to interfere with SLMC affairs relating to its authority on standards of foreign or other higher education institutes
The officials from the Attorney General’s Department, the Higher Education Ministry, Health Ministry and University Grants Commission are scheduled to attend the meeting.
Meanwhile, Deputy Minister Harsha de Silva told our news team that the SLMC has written to him about their decision.
He said that it was the SLMC that had requested the meeting.

hits._id: Sri Lanka Ranked No.50 In Human Capital Index

_source.content:
Sri Lanka is at No.50 in the worldwide Human Capital Index (HCI), which was launched today (29) by the World Economic Forum (WEF).
Finland topped the index which measures a country’s ability to nurture, develop and deploy talent for economic growth.
 “The Index covers six countries in the South Asian region including Sri Lanka (50), Bhutan (91), Bangladesh (104), India (105), Nepal (108) and Pakistan (118). The overall average score for the region is 59.92,” the WEF stated.
The WEF stated that Sri Lanka was a bright spot for the region which benefited from strong educational enrolment and basic education completion rates as well as positive perceptions of the quality of its primary schools and education system overall (23rd on both).
The region’s most populous countries -- Bangladesh, India and Pakistan are held back by insufficient educational enrolment rates and poor quality primary schools. The youth literacy rate in the three countries stands at 83%, 89% and 75% respectively, far behind other emerging markets as well as.
Meanwhile, Norway, Switzerland, Canada and Japan were ranked 2 to 5 respectively while Mauritania ranked last in the list.

hits._id: India Offers Scholarships To Children Of Lankan Estate Workers

_source.content:
The Indian Government has invited applications from children of estate workers, who are resident on estates, for award of scholarships by the Ceylon Estate Workers’ Education Trust (CEWET).
These scholarships are available for G.C.E. Advanced Level, Undergraduate courses and for students undergoing Vocational/ Technical education in any other Government Technical Colleges in Sri Lanka.
The Indian High Commission in Colombo said that students who have passed G.C.E. Ordinary Level (with minimum 6 credit passes) or Advanced Level examination and below 25 years of age are eligible to apply. The completed applications forms must be accompanied by photocopies of birth certificate, result sheet of G.C.E ‘O’ Level or ‘A’ Level, latest salary slip of parents and Estate Superintendent’s certificate regarding parent’s occupation. Application forms could be downloaded at the High Commission of India, Colombo website www.hcicolombo.org.
Application forms could also be obtained from the High Commission of India, 36-38, Galle Road, Colombo-03 and the Assistant High Commission of India, No.31, Rajaphilla Mawatha, Kandy.
Duly completed forms should reach the Honorary Secretary, CEWET c/o High Commission of India, P.O. Box 882, Colombo-03 on or before 30th August, 2016, the Indian High Commission in Colombo said.

hits._id: No ISIS In Sri Lanka: Sagala Rathnayake

_source.content:
ISIS operations are not carried out in Sri Lanka and the Government has taken adequate measures to prevent foreign terrorist organizations from making use of Sri Lanka, the Minister of Law and Order and Southern Development Sagala Ratnayaka confirmed to Parliament yesterday.
Creating a religious dialogue and awareness with the co-ordination of Muslim politicians, religious leaders, Ministry of Education, Department of Muslim Religious and Cultural Affairs and civil organizations such as All Ceylon Jamiyathul Ulma (ACJU) and National Shoora Council are the key measures the Government has taken in order to dissuade the Muslim community from joining in extremist activities.
According to the Minister, necessary action is now underway with the assistance of teachers as well as parents to represent all the communities at schools. Supervision of the immigration and emigration system for identified extremists in the country and people who return from countries known for terrorism after engaging in foreign education, occupations or other activities is also a measure properly in place. Adding more to the list, the Government has also prevented the propaganda spread of extremist ideas though social media, and taken proper measures against this by deactivating accounts that spread ISIS ideas, as well as taking legal action against any lecturers or institutions who propagate such extremist ideas.

hits._id: Suraksha insurance scheme for schoolchildren launched

_source.content:
The national ceremony to mark the inauguration of the ‘Suraksha’ Insurance scheme introduced by the Ministry of Education was held under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe at Temple Trees this morning (02).
The beneficiaries of this scheme will include nearly 4.5 million students between 5 to 19 years of age.
Students attending government schools, assisted private schools, non-assisted private schools, international schools and student monks are included in the scheme.
Sources from the Ministry of Education have stated that registration for the insurance scheme is compulsory and all data files relating to them are now being processed.
Students need not pay any premium for this insurance as all relevant payments are made by the government.
The Government initially allocated 2,700 million rupees towards this scheme under the 2017 budget and the scheme is being handled by the Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation.
The maximum annual cover for hospitalization and medical services for a child is Rs. 200,000.
Expenses up to Rs.100,000 at a time could be reimbursed for a child for a hospitalization.
Medical examinations fees without hospitalization could also be reimbursed.
When a child obtains treatment from a government hospital, payment of Rs.100 per day will be paid for a period of 30 days.
When in-house treatment from a government hospital is obtained, a maximum of Rs.10,000 would be paid for diagnostic laboratory tests conducted outside.
If treatment is obtained from any private hospital registered with the Health Ministry, a maximum payment of Rs.100,000 will be paid at a given time.
Children receiving treatment under the ‘Suraksha’ scheme will be entitled to a 20 percent discount on hospital charges and medical consultant fees.
This follows a discussion between the Education Minister and the Private Hospital Association and Consultant Medical Practitioners’ Association.
The maximum room charges for a day paid at a private hospital, ward at a government hospital or a fee-levying Ayurveda Hospital is Rs.5000.
Maximum room charges paid per annum will be Rs.60, 000.
There is also a provision to obtain insurance cover for treatment and doctors charges, even without hospitalization, as there is an annual cover up to a maximum of Rs.10,000 for 7 types of illnesses.
In the event of a child’s death due to an accident, Rs.100, 000 will be paid as compensation.
In the event of a parents death Rs.75,000 with be allocated towards the child’s education.
If a student suffers permanent disability, Rs.100, 000 will be paid as compensation while Rs.50,000 will be paid as compensation for partial disability.
During his address, President Maithripala Sirisena stated that the government is dedicated to protecting the nation’s children.

The leader of the House, Minister Lakshman Kiriella says that the Judicature (Amendment) Draft Bill will not be tabled in Parliament today (Apr. 05).
 
He told the House in line with the Supreme Court ruling that several clauses of the Draft Bill are being amended.
 
Meanwhile, Education Minister Akila Viraj Kariyawasam said that conducting of tuition classes will be banned during the school time, in the future.
 
Minister Kariyawasam said this in response to a question raised by MP Vasudeva Nanayakkara.
 
A Supplementary Bill seeking Rs. 7 billion was also tabled in Parliament.

hits._id: Minister Mahinda Samarasinghe delegates power to state Minister Palitha

_source.content:
The Minister of Skilled Development and Vocational Training Mahinda Samarasinghe has delegated power of several subjects and purview coming under him to his State Minister Palitha Range Bandara.
The relevant gazette notification was issued on August 25th.
Accordingly, power of the Technical Education and Training Department has been delegated to State minister Palitha Range Bandara.
At the same time, training youths at international standards for foreign employment has also been placed under State Minister Range Bandara.
However the State Minister told our news team that he is not satisfied with the delegation of authority.

hits._id: An A/L examination hall Supervisor steps down voluntarily

_source.content:
A supervisor at an examination centre at the Kandy Girls’ High School has voluntarily stepped down from the post.
The examination department said that the supervisor had stepped down from the post after making the reason known in the log book.
It was also reported that on August 2 notes-writing paper relevant for some other subject had been distributed to students sitting the Economics multiple choice question paper for writing their answers.
Central Province Education Director Thilak Ekanayake said that as a result of this, the examination candidates were severely inconvenienced

hits._id: 13 schools closed for Poson in Anuradhapura, Mihintale and Thanthirimale

_source.content:
Thirteen schools will be closed to accommodate security forces deployed for Poson Poya Day work in Anuradhapura, Mihintale and Thanthirimale areas.
Accordingly the schools will be closed from 16th to 22nd, Department of Education of the North Central Province said.
Anuradhapura Maha Vidyalaya, Swarnapali Girls High School, St. Joseph High School, Walisingha Harishchandra College, Nivattaka Chethiya College, Zahira College, Devanampiyatissa Maha Vidyalaya, Vivekananda College and Mahabodhi Vidyalaya will be thus closed.
In addition, Mihintale Maha Vidyalaya, Mihintale Maha Vidyalaya Junior College, Kammalakkulama College and Tantirimale Wimalagnana Maha Vidyalaya will also remain closed.

hits._id: A problem about the health care of students of 9096 schools.

_source.content: The Public Health Inspector’s union says that although there are 10,098, only 1002 schools implement the canteen policy.Participating at a media briefing held in Colombo yesterday PHI union chairman Upul Rohana said that accordingly as a result of the policy not being implemented in 9096 schools, a problem has cropped up with regard to the health care of schoolchildren.The PHI union chairman said because of this it was necessary to add a relevant clause to the Food Act to the effect that schoolchildren’s the health care was ensured by the Education Ministry.

hits._id: Minister S B rejects a written agreement of the solution to the AHS dispute.-Video

_source.content: Higher Education Minister S.B. Dissanayake said that he is not ready to give a written agreement of the solution given by the President to Allied Health Science dispute.During a meeting held at the Kandy District Secretariat today, Minister Dissanayake announced this in response to a statement made by Inter University Students Federation Convener Najith Indika yesterday.Addressing a media briefing held in Colombo yesterday, IUSF Convener Najith Indika said that the students protest will be continued until a written agreement with regard to the President’s solution to the Allied Health Science dispute is given.

hits._id: Southern preschools closed until next Monday

_source.content:
All preschools in the Southern province will be closed from tomorrow, until 27th of May.
 
The Southern Provincial Education Ministry said the decision was taken due to infectious fever epidemic spreading in the area.
 
The health authorities said that 13 persons including 11 children have so far died of the disease.Meanwhile, a group of experts has been sent to South by the Ministry of Health to probe and advise remedial action to contain the spread of the viral flu.It is suspected the flu is spread by adino and influenza viruses.

hits._id: Anti-SAITM strike ends

_source.content:
The Government Medical Officers’ Association says that the strike which was launched from 8am yesterday (21) is now over.
The strike was launched demanding that Malabe Private Medical College be abolished. 
A number of health, education and other trade unions took part in the strike.
Daily activities at hospitals, schools and universities were severely inconvenienced due to yesterday’s strike.
GMOA executive committee member Dr. Prasaad Colombage said that although the token strike would end today, yet another decisive step would be taken in the future, if the government continues with its stance on SAITM.

hits._id: Number of Dengue patients exceed 69,380

_source.content: The number of Dengue patients during the past period has exceeded 69,380 by now.200 deaths have been reported and the majority has been reported from the Western Province, says Epidemiology Unit.Health Ministry says that the percentage of school children getting Dengue fever has increased by 20%.Specally, the reason for this increment has been that the Dengue carriers are in action during the time between 6.00am and 9.00am.Accordingly, Ministry of Health in collaboration with the Ministry of Education has commenced a cleaning program in schools which is conducted from 11.00am to 12.00 noon.

hits._id: Complaint filed against SAITM CEO

_source.content:
The All Ceylon Medical Officers Association filed a complaint with police headquarters against SAITM CEO Dr. Sameera Senaratne this morning.
The Association charges that Dr. Senaratne poses as a medical doctor without having registration with the Sri Lanka Medical Council.
National Organizer of the All Ceylon Medical Officers Association Dr. Sameera Asanga commented on the complaint to our news team.
In addition, doctors attached to Karapitiya Teaching Hospital in Galle organized a public meeting against SAITM in Galle yesterday.
Meanwhile, Public Rights Protection Collective distributed leaflets to educate people on free education.

hits._id: Doctors to go on strike; Nurses Unions also hold discussions

_source.content: The Government Medical Officers Association is preparing to resort to trade union action against the budget cuts affecting health and education sectors. Secretary of the GMOA Doctor Naveen De Soyza said that they would conduct protests in front of hospitals tomorrow. Meanwhile, Nurses Unions are also conducting discussions to enter in to a strike action over the steps taken through a circular issued by the Ministry of Health. Chairman of the All Island Health Services Union Gamini Kumarasinghe stated that the circular had cancelled back wages due to nurses since 2003.

hits._id: Strike by University non-academic staff ends

_source.content:
The trade union action launched by Non-Academic University staff from the 27th of July was discontinued after a discussion held with University Education and Highway Minister Lakshman Kiriella today.
Non-Academic staff of 15 universities and their affiliated institutes throughout the island joined the strike on 7 demands, including monthly lieu allowance and a systematic pension scheme.
University Trade Unions Joint Committee stated that it decided to stop the strike and return to work immediately subsequent to the written pledge by the ministry to fulfil their demands.

hits._id: The child, who was forcefully seated in a class by the mother, has been removed

_source.content:
A child who was made to sit in class by force has been expelled. The incident happened at Ananda National School in Chilaw last Friday.
This mother staged a protest on five occasions demanding that her child be readmitted to class. However she failed on all occasions, she entered her child by force to Year one class on last Friday.
When our news team contacted Education Director of the North Western Province J.G.N. Thilakaratna said that an investigation is being carried out to ascertain whether any injustice has been occurred to the child.

hits._id: Marathon students death to be investigated

_source.content: Education Minister Akila Viraj Kariyawasam states that a special investigation will be carried out following the tragic death of Chamod Sathsara of Ambalantota Bolana Navodya Vidyalaya who died yesterday during a Marathon.The sample body parts of Chamod Sathsara have been sent to the Government Analyst.Doctors who held the post mortem at the Hambantota hospital last afternoon have given an open verdict, and samples of the body parts have been sent to the Government Analyst for further investigation.A hospital spokesman told our news team however Chamod had died when he was brought to hospital.

hits._id: Principal who sold desks and chairs for scrap iron arrested

_source.content: The principal of Ananda College in Puttalam who was accused of selling iron frames of desks and chairs of the school for scrap metal for 35,000 rupees was arrested by the police today.The complaint against the 52 year old principal was lodged by a member of the school welfare society.Police media spokesperson SSP Ajith Rohana stated that the chairs and desks were brought to the school from another school in Kalpitiya with the permission of the zonal education director.The arrested principal is scheduled to be produced before court tomorrow.

hits._id: People in the N & S were bestowed with the greatest gift of freedom; President

_source.content:
President Mahinda Rajapaksa yesterday said the people in the North and South were bestowed with the greatest gift of freedom by the government after three decades of conflict.
President said the government is taking every possible effort to provide what is required for the people.
The President stressed the government ensured the people’s right to live in the country free from fear and intimidation.
He said a peaceful environment dawned for all children to pursue their education without fear and make use of the facilities made available to them by the government.

hits._id: New mobile app to track ragging in universities

_source.content:
Minister of Higher Education and Cultural Affairs Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe says that 280 cases of harassment and sexual abuse during university ragging had been reported so far.
 
He said this introducing a new app in an attempt to prevent ragging at universities.
 
The new app was launched by the University Grants Commission in Colombo today (Jun 06).
 
The new app allows the vice chancellors and marshals at universities to track the victims of ragging.
 
Then the authorities could be informed of the incident by the victim through an SMS.

hits._id: SL-Pakistan Foreign Office consultations begin

_source.content:
The Foreign Secretaries of Sri Lanka and Pakistan, Prasad Kariyawasam and Tehmina Janjua, will lead the respective Foreign Ministry delegations to the Fifth Foreign Office consultations that will take place in Colombo tomorrow (17).
Discussions during the consultations are expected to focus on all relevant areas of cooperation between the two countries including trade and investment, tourism, science and technology, education, immigration, defence and sports.
Foreign Office Consultations between the two countries were last held in Islamabad in 2014.
The Pakistan Foreign Secretary Janjua will pay a courtesy call on President Maithripala Sirisena tomorrow.

hits._id: Protests across the island over teacher shortages

_source.content:
Several protests are underway across the island demanding solution to teacher shortages in schools.
A group of parents protested in front of Heenatiya Maha Vidyalaya in Balapitiya yesterday claiming that the school does not have a grade five teacher.
In the meantime, a separate protest was launched by parents in front of the zonal education office urging authorities to halt the transfer of 108 teachers temporarily.
Few of the parents met representatives of the zone’s teacher transfer board. Later it was decided to temporarily halt the transfer of grade five teachers till September.

hits._id: Major change in Concept of Education

_source.content: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe states that the concept and process of education has undergone a major change.A school is not complete with only buildings.While attending a ceremony to declare open a new building at Colombo Royal College this morning, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe stated that new technology should be utilized to a great extent.The Prime Minister reiterated that a school is completed with buildings as well as computer technology, labs and library facilities.He also stated that the new building has been built in the same premises where he studied 50 years ago.

hits._id: BC summons Ex-Minister Bandula

_source.content: The former Education Minister Bandula Gunawardana reported again to the Bribery Commission this morning.The former minister visited the Bribery Commission to request its officials to expedite the inquiry made against him.Lanka Teachers Association made a complaint against former minister Bandula Gunawardana and the former ministry secretary on February 5th.The Teachers Association charged that several irregularities have been taken place in implementing the Mahindodaya Technical laboratory project.The former minister visited the Bribery Commission for the first time on February 6th and requested its officials to inquire the complaint as soon.

hits._id: President meets Sri Lankans in Rome

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapksa extended the official invitation yesterday to His Holiness Pope Francis who is scheduled to visit the island next January.At the cordial discussions between the President and His Holiness, President Rajapaksa informed His Holiness of the progress made in resettling internally displaced persons, progress made in the clearing of landmines, infrastructure development and progress made in health, education and power supply.After the meeting with His Holiness President Rajapaksa had a discussion with His Eminence Pietro Cardinal Parolin, Secretary of State and Prime Minister of the Holy See.

hits._id: Greater confidence on local farmers & entrepreneurs: reiterates President.-Video

hits._id: New Zealand offers full support for Commonwealth Conference.

_source.content:
New Zealand Foreign Minister Murray McCully re-affirmed his country’s support for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting that will take place in Sri Lanka in November when he called on President Mahinda Rajapaksa at Temple Trees yesterday.
 
Minister McCully wished Sri Lanka well in preparing for CHOGM and said the entire Commonwealth needs to see the progress in the country, pointing out that success in trade and the economy is important to the process.
 
President Rajapaksa and McCully also spoke about several other areas of mutual interest including agriculture, tourism and education.

hits._id: University non-academic strike suspended

_source.content:
University non-academic strike suspended"The university non-academic staff has decided to call off their strike.
They launched the strike on 27th of February.
The Ministry Higher Education yesterday (Apr. 11) announced that the non-academic staff serving under probation, casual, temporary, substitute, training or under contract basis will be considered as having vacated their posts if they do not report to duty before 17th of April.
The permanent staff who do not report for duty will be considered as having taken no-pay leave during the period of the strike.

hits._id: All obligations towards the Buddha Sasana will be upheld- President

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena said that the task of securing the Buddhist Dispensation would be fulfilled by building Sri Lanka as a centre of Theravada Buddhism.
The president made the statement during a meeting with the national Buddhist Intellectual Council at President’s office yesterday.
The Council praised the efforts that were being made to ensure the progress of Pirivena education.
On this occasion attention was drawn toward preparing a stable development programme centered on Buddhist Temples.
At this meeting the President also pointed out the importance of developing strong curriculums for religious studies in schools.

hits._id: President Instructs Officials To Expand Paddy Storage Facilities

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena has instructed relevant officials to expand the storage facilities throughout the island to purchase paddy in the upcoming season without a delay.
The President gave these instructions while speaking at the special meeting of the Polonnaruwa district coordinating committee held at the education college of Polonnaruwa. He also instructed the officials to handover a report regarding the paddy storage facilities available in Polonnaruwa district.
The President also informed them to be ready to purchase paddy in the upcoming season by setting up temporary storages or constructing new ones.

_source.content:
Four councilors of the Eastern Provincial Council including two Tamil National Alliance (TNA) councilors sworn in as provincial ministers short while ago,  at the office of the governor of the province.

hits._id: Higher education Ministry gets ready to obtain the finger prints of all university students.

_source.content: The Higher Education Ministry has decided to prepare a method for computerizing the finger prints of all university students.A senior ministry spokesman told our news team that the ministry was currently preparing the relevant set of proposals.In this methodology all the information about the student will be linked to the finger print.The senior spokesman said further that the main aim of this was to certify student attendance.Currently student attendance is certified through signatures.By the new method it will be possible to retrieve information about student attention and other relevant particulars instantly through the computer.

hits._id: Vice Chancellor of the University of Colombo given ultimatum by FUTA

_source.content:
The Federation of University Teachers Alliance states that newly appointed Vice Chancellor of the University of Colombo Dr. Kumara Hirimburegama has been given two weeks ultimatum to vacate his post.
 
A ballot was held last week to select the Vice Chancellor for the Colombo University & Professor Lakshman Dissanayake was able to secure majority votes in the ballot against Dr. Hirimburegama.
 
When contacted the Secretary of the Ministry of Higher Education Dr. Sunil Jayantha Navarathne said the President has made the new appointment under the powers vested in him by the Constitution.

hits._id: President reiterates the importance of a social service on behalf of children

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena stated in his Universal Children's Day message that the government is committed to improve child nutrition and childcare.
He stated that we are universally bound to provide proper nutrition and healthcare to all children, ensure their right to education and create a space for them to be born and brought up in a safe environment.
However, as a nation, we cannot be satisfied about the ensuring of all these needs of our children.
Sri Lanka has to overcome the challenges in the areas of child nutrition, education, child abuse and violence against children.
President Maithripala Sirisena stated in a message to mark the International Day of Older Persons that It is our responsibility to ensure the freedom and protection and the esteem of the elderly people,
Issuing a message Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe said children are our greatest asset; as a nation, the responsibility is ours to ensure the creation of an environment in which children can grow up to become confident, caring adults, conscious of their social responsibilities.
Today is not only the day the world celebrates children but also the day we remember our elders; The World Elders Day also falls today.
The Premier said “as a community, we have a social obligation to the children and to the elders among us to assure their well-being while attending to their needs”.

hits._id: President focuses on increasing Mahapola scholarships : video

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapaksa says that the government is taking steps to empower northern youth who had lost certain rights due to terrorism in the past.Participating in a Twitter discussion, President Rajapaksa said that northern students excelled the GCE O/ Level examination last year due to the government’s youth empowering program in the province.During the International Youth Forum’s inaugural ceremony in Hambantota a few days ago, the President invited participants to his Twitter discussion.Accordingly, the discussion was held this afternoon.Most of the questions posed for the President were regarding youth education, employment and empowering of women.During the Twitter discussion, President Rajapaksa said the government has drawn its attention to increase the cash allowance given to recipients of the Mahapola scholarship.He tweeted that 10% of university students are in dire need of some assistance.He also said that the government generally takes steps to productively improve education in the country including upgrading 1000 schools to a fully fledged level.When asked whether the government has any plans to ban social media websites such as Facebook and Twitter he said that his sons will be the first to raise objections if such a move is initiated.He said that over 300,000 fans have “Liked” him on Facebook and he had over 25,000 followers on Twitter and so he would not ban social media websites in the country.

hits._id: Human Rights Commission probes Madaatugama girl’s complaint

_source.content:
The Sri Lanka Human Rights Commission conducted a seven-hour inquiry into the complaint relating to the girl who had been expelled from her school after being accused of getting pregnant.
 
She was studying at Madaatugama Government School in the Kekirawa Education Zone.
 
The Human Rights Commission had earlier commenced an inquiry regarding the incident after this incident was reported by media.
 
The girl and the parents were present at the hearing.
 
The principal and several other teachers were also summoned to the HR Commission for the inquiry.
 
However, the Education Ministry decided to suspend the services of the school principal who had expelled the girl from the school.
 
Education Minister Akila Viraaj Kaariyawasam instructed the authorities to take necessary steps to provide a school for the girl.
 
In this incident, the girl, who is extremely poor, had vomited at the school recently due to having come to school without having breakfast.
 
But the school principal thinking that the girl is pregnant, based on information provided by few of her friends had called her parents to the school and had dismissed her from school.
 
However, after being admitted to the Dambulla hospital the doctors who examined her confirmed that she had neither conceived nor had been subjected to any abuse.
 
Similarly, the hospital authorities informed the National Child Protection Authority about the incident. 
 
Meanwhile, the mother of two in Balangoda who was imprisoned after signing bail papers on behalf her husband was released.
 
This was following the revelations made by Hiru news team, which resulted in contributors offering a sum of 100,000 rupees in order to settle the bail at the Balangoda Magistrate’s Court yesterday (30).
 
Our news team revealed recently regarding a 24-year-old mother of two who was imprisoned after signing a personal bond on behalf of her husband who was charged with assaulting an individual.
 
The mother of two was sentenced to 6 months imprisonment after her husband failed to appear before courts.
 
Following her imprisonment, the children of the ages 2 and 3 were in the care of her mother.
 
However, following the revelation by Hiru news, the Department of Customs Friends’ Union contributed the Rs. 100,000 which was needed for her release.

hits._id: Eight hospitalized in Badulla clash

_source.content:
8 persons including 2 Provincial Councillors who received injuries during the tense situation erupted in the Uva Provincial Council premises were admitted to Badulla Hospital today (Jan. 25).
The 2 Council members were assaulted while they were arriving at the Provincial Council to participate in the council session this morning.
Later police were called in to control the situation.
Our correspondent said that a group of supporters of Senthil Thondaman who was sworn in as the Tamil Education Minister of the Province yesterday was waiting at the Provincial council premises to welcome the new Minister when the clash occurred.
At this juncture, Uva Opposition Leader R. M. Ratnayake and UNP Councillors A. Ganeshamurthi and Upali Senarathna arrived at the Council by around 10 am.
