hits._id: Update: Prime Minister also appoints a committee to investigate police attack on HNDA students

_source.content:
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe has appointed a special committee chaired by the Secretary of the ministry of power Dr. Suren Batagoda to investigate the police attack on the HNDA students.Meanwhile the National Police Commission decided today to appoint a three member committee to further investigate the police attack on the HNDA students.At the same time, the collective of HNDA and Inter University Student Federation lodged a complaint with the Human Right Commission today seeking justice to their plight.Students pursuing the Higher National Diploma of Accountancy staged a protest in front of the Higher Education Ministry last Thursday demanding the authorities to upgrade the level to their diploma to degree level.Nine students were hospitalized after police fired tear gas, water canon and baton charged the protesting students.39 students were arrested and they were released on bail when produced before Court on the following day.Meanwhile following summons by the Police Commission, several senior police officers including Acting IGP Pujitha Jayasundera and DIG in Charge of Colombo Gamini Mathurata appeared before the Police Commission this morning.Later Secretary of the Police Commission Ariyadasa Corey told the media during a press briefing that the Commission Chairman has decided to appoint a three member committee to further investigate the incident.  Update: Monday, 02 November 2015 - 19:10-----------------------------------------------------Police commission appoints a 3 member committee to further investigate the police attack on HNDA students.The National Police Commission has decided to appoint a three member committee to investigate the attack by the police on HNDA students in front of the Higher Education Ministry.

The Secretary of the Police Commission Ariyadasa Coorey said that this committee, comprising of three senior administrative officers, would take action to obtain a report on the incident.

Meanwhile, following summons by the Police Commission, Acting IGP Pujitha Jayasundera and the DIG in Charge of Colombo Gamini Mathurata appeared before the Police Commission this morning.
  
Students pursuing the Higher National Diploma of Accountancy staged a protest in front of the Higher Education Ministry last Thursday, demanding authorities to upgrade the level of their diploma to a degree.

Subsequently, the police fired tear gas, water cannons and baton charged the crowd and, nine students were hospitalized after they received injuries due to this attack.

The injured students are now preparing to lodge a complaint with the Human Right Commission today.

The Convener of the Inter University Students Federation Lahiru Weerasekera further described about their move to go before the Human Rights Commission.
 
He further said that one of the injured students Sashini Sandeepani of the Dehiwala Higher Education Technical Institute was hospitalized again last night to undergo further testing.

Meanwhile, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe ordered the Minster of Law and Order to provide him a full report of the incident.

The Minister of Law and Order Thilak Marapana said that the initial report of the investigation conducted after the incident would be submitted to the Prime Minister today.
  
The Secretary of the Police Commission Ariyadasa Coorey also described the investigation, currently being conducted by the Commission to our news team.

hits._id: Recommendations to reduce age limit by one year for year one school admission

_source.content:
The National Education Commission has recommended to the government that the age limit to admit students into year one should be reduced by one year.
Commission Secretary Nilakshi Gunesekera told our news team that the current age limit to admit students to Year One would be reduced from 5 to children aged  4 years old.
In addition, the Commission has drawn attention to reduce school grades by one year and re-set it from grade 6 to 8.
Commission Secretary Gunesekera further said that other schools which maintain grades from Year 9 to Year 12 will be renamed as Secondary Schools under the new reforms.

hits._id: 60 hostels to house university students within the next 2 years.

_source.content:
The Higher Education Ministry has decided to complete the construction of the 60 hostels to house university students within the next 2 years.

hits._id: Increase On Value Added Tax Will Be Effective From Today

_source.content:
Valued Added Tax (VAT) which previously stood at 11 percent has been increased to 15 percent with affect from today, Finance Minister Ravi Karunanayake said.
Minister Karunanayake said education sector and pharmaceutical drugs have been exempted from the increase.
Import or supply of telecommunication equipment or machinery, high tech equipment including copper cables for telecom industry and the issue of license to local telecom operators by Telecommunication Regulatory Commission are Liable for the increased VAT.
The supply of goods or services to any specified project other than housing projects approved on or after May 5th, 2016, will be taxed.
The minister was speaking at a press conference at his ministry yesterday.

hits._id: President to visit Pakistan.

_source.content: Sri Lanka and Pakistan have reaffirmed their resolve to strengthen cooperation in countering terrorism and transnational crime in a comprehensive manner.During a meeting between the foreign secretaries of the two countries today, the two sides agreed to enhance cooperation in combating drug and human trafficking, handling asylum seekers and other transnational crimes and to continue the cooperation with renewed vigor, which includes training of security personnel.Foreign Secretaries of Pakistan Aizaz Ahmed Chaudhry and his Sri Lankan counterpart Kshenuka Seneviratne yesterday held Fourth round of Political Consultations at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Islamabad.During the meeting, the Foreign Secretaries, while recognizing the close and friendly relations the two countries enjoy, have agreed that further consolidation of relations is needed in diverse areas.They particularly sought enhanced cooperation in the fields of trade, education, culture and defence.Expressing appreciation for the support received from Pakistan at the international fora, especially against the UN resolution at the recent UNHRC session in Geneva, Sri Lankan Foreign Secretary briefed her Pakistani counterpart on the current developments in Sri Lanka including the efforts on rehabilitation, reconciliation and resettlement in the war-torn areas.The two sides, while acknowledging each other's support in education sphere, have agreed to further diversify and strengthen existing collaboration in the field of education.Ground for Sri Lankan President Mahinda Rajapaksa's visit to Pakistan later this month was also prepared during the consultations.During the President's visit, the leaders of the two nations are expected to evaluate bilateral relations and identify potential areas for further cooperation to the mutual benefit.

hits._id: SAITM qualification not accepted by British Medical Council

_source.content:
The regulator of the medical education in Britain, General Medical Council has added Malabe Private Medical College, SAITM to their list of medical qualifications that are not accepted in Britain.
The list included a number of medical colleges from around the world. India’s Ranchi University - Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College is also in it.
The GMC said in its website that they do not accept applications to sit the PLAB test or for registration from graduates of the listed medical schools.
The PLAB test is the main route by which International Medical Graduates demonstrate that they have the necessary skills and knowledge to practice medicine in the UK.For more details : http://www.gmc-uk.org/doctors/registration_applications/14390.asp

Agriculture and agrarian services, animal husbandry, irrigation and water supply, food supply and distribution, environment and cooperative development will be under Minister Ponnathurai Aingaraneshan.
Education, Cultural affairs, Sports and youth affairs will be under provincial minister Thambiraja Guruku-laraj.
Fisheries, Transport, Trade and commerce, Agrarian development, Road development and Motor vehicle transportation will be under minister Balasubramaniyam Deniswaram.

hits._id: President returns after a successful tour in Europe

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena who was touring in Europe arrived at Katunayake airport this morning.
The president said that he is returning to Sri Lanka winning a number of benefits for the development of the country.
During his two day official visit to Austria President Sirisena met Sri Lankan expats living in Vienna, Austria. The meeting was organized by Austria’s Sri Lankan Union.
Stating that today Sri Lanka has no enemies, president added all aid will be taken from the world to develop the country.
Meanwhile, leading organizations in Austria have pledged to invest in Sri Lanka and also are aiming to increase bilateral relations between the two countries in trade, tourism and education fields.

hits._id: Law students in a protest demanding question papers in 3 languages.-Video

_source.content: All Ceylon Law Students’ Movement launched a protest opposite the Fort Railway Station this morning.The protest was launched for not providing Tamil and Sinhala translations for the 1st, 2nd and 3rd year examination paper.They oppose the decision taken by the Council of Legal Education to provide question papers only in English language.Subsequent to the protest they are due to reach the Presidential Secretariat in a protest march to handover a letter.We made inquires in this regard from the principal of the law college Dr. Jayatissa de Costa.He said that they have been issuing question papers only in English for several years.However he pointed out that the students are given the option of answering in any of the 3 languages.

hits._id: No candidates allowed at school events; Election commissioner informs education Ministry

_source.content: The Election Commissioner has issued a circular to the Department of Education instructing Principals not to involve election candidates and supporting politicians in school ceremonies.The circular stated that such actions could promote the image of candidates therefore the action has been categorized as a violation of election rules.Meanwhile Election Commissioner Mahinda Deshapriya had a discussion with the Secretaries of all political parties at his office in Rajagiriya this morning.Attention was drawn to certain former PC ministers and PC members who have not returned their official assets including official vehicles.The Commissioner insisted that the cost of official assets and vehicles should be charged from the candidates if they violate election rules and use them continuously.

hits._id: Principle who went for leadership training meets with sudden death

_source.content:
A principal who had taken part in a leadership training programme organized at the Rantambe Cadet Training Institute has passed away due to a heart attack which occurred this morning.
 
According to the Hasalaka police the decease has been identified as 52 year old W.A. Wickremesinghe, principal of the Raddolugama Pagngnnananda College.
 
The Ceylon Teachers Union meanwhile has raised concerns to ascertain if the deceased principal had undergone a fitness test prior to being enrolled into the programme.
 
Chairman of the CTU Joseph Stallin speaking in this regard expressed the following views to our news team.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
Although attempts were made by our news team to contact the Secretary to the Ministry of Education in this regard it proved futile.

hits._id: No exclusion of any subjects; Min. of Education

_source.content:
Minister of Education Bandula Gunawardhana says that the government has not drawn a policy decision to exclude any subject pertaining to the GCE Advanced level examination.
 
However Minister Gunawardhana noted that a new subject stream complemented by the subject of technology had been added to the GCE Advanced Level syllabus.
 
Among the new subjects introduced are Engineering Technology & Science & Technology.
 
The new stream of subjects would be amalgamated to the existing syllabus from the 15th of July onwards.
 
News paper reports carried today however noted that plans were underway to do away with the Business Statistics subject due for the GCE Advance Level syllabus.
 
Minister Bandula Gunawardhana made this observation while commenting this.

hits._id: Health Ministry implementing recommendations on Castle Street Hospital

_source.content:
The Ministry of Health stated that it has started to implement the recommendations of the Special Committee which was appointed to probe the death of two pregnant women at the Intensive Care Unit of the Castle Street Hospital for Women.
 
The Committee found that the cause of death of the two patients was ‘Influenza A’ virus.
 
During a seminar held today at the Bureau of Health Education, Director General of Health Services Dr.Palitha Mahipala stated that the ICU of the Castle Street Hospital for Women will be re-tested after it is cleaned.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
Meanwhile Director of the Castle Street Hospital for Women Dr. W.K. Wickramasinghe said that another 9 patients are quarantined and being treated for ‘Influenza A’ virus.

hits._id: University students protest in Pettah

_source.content:
A protest was held in front of Pettah Bo tree this afternoon demanding the release of University student activists and the abolition of Malabe Private Medical College.
A heavy traffic jam was created on the Olcott Mawatha, Pettah due to this protest by the IUSF activists, GMOA members and representatives of several other trade unions.
Our correspondent stated that the protestors burnt tyres and effigies to show their protest.
Meanwhile, the Minister of Higher Education Lakshman Kiriella says the Government is prepared to accept any solution to solve the SAITM issue without closing down the institute.
He also said that the final decision will be taken by courts as the issue is already in courts.

hits._id: A Commission appointed to find solutions to SAITM crisis

_source.content:
A public Commission has been appointed to find solutions to the crises that have cropped up in relation to Malabe Private Medical College.
The appointing of the relevant Commission comprising of 6 members took place at the Colombo BMICH yesterday (12).
The commission will function for 28 days beginning on October 16.
Action has been taken to have its report released on November 19.
The Commission will investigate the commencement of the Malabe Private Medical College, its history, management, current crises that have cropped up in medical education and medical sector because of this college.
Similarly, the Commission has decided to obtain the views of politicians, government officials, student movements, trade unions and students’ parents.

hits._id: Bilateral discussions between the President and his Russian counterpart commences

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena met Russian President Vladimir Putin a short while ago at the Kremlin Palace. President Maithripala Sirisena was received with a Guard of Honour at the Kremlin’s Alexander Garden when he visited the Red Square to place a wreath at the Tomb of Unknown Soldier.  The Military Commandant of Moscow received the President at the magnificent War Memorial and the President inspected the Guard of Honour before placing the wreath. hits._id: Austria keen to strengthen bilateral ties with Sri Lanka

_source.content:
During the bilateral discussions held at Austrian President Fischer's office after the welcoming ceremony, the leaders of Austria and Sri Lanka agreed to increase the cooperation in the economic development between the two countries.
Following the bilateral discussions, President Sirisena and his Austrian counterpart Fischer held a joint press conference.
Addressing the joint press conference, leaders of the heads of the governments stated that their hope is to further enhance the existing bilateral ties between the two countries and initiate stronger bilateral relations in sports, culture and education sectors.

hits._id: Rajarata uni students in front of Higher Education Ministry for 3 hours.-Video

hits._id: Video: The Cabinet decides not to cancel the Year-5 Scholarship Examination

hits._id: Prince Edward to attend Independence Day celebrations

_source.content:
Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex and the Countess, will be arriving in Sri Lanka today (Jan.31).
Prince Edward is the youngest child of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip.
They will represent 'The Queen' at the 70th-anniversary celebration of Sri Lanka’s Independence on 4th of February.
The Earl and Countess will travel to Colombo and other parts of Sri Lanka, celebrating the long-standing friendship between the two countries and shared interest in the Commonwealth, youth development and education.

hits._id: Uva clash: 6 arrested

_source.content:
Six persons have been arrested in connection with the assault on Uva UNP Provincial Councilor, A. Ganeshamurthi.
 
He was assaulted during a clash at the Uva Provincial Council premises yesterday (Jan. 25).
 
Police said that the suspects are receiving treatment under police protection in the Badulla General Hospital.
 
They are scheduled to be produced before Badulla Magistrate today.
 
Councilor, Ganeshamurthi, who was also injured in the assault, is still receiving treatment.
 
A tense situation erupted both within and outside the Uva Provincial Council premises yesterday between supporters of newly appointed Minister of Tamil Education in Uva, Senthil Thondaman and Ganeshmurthi.

hits._id: South Korean Foreign Minister meets the Prime Minister

_source.content:
During a meeting with Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe at temple trees yesterday, South Koreas Minister of Foreign Affairs, Yun Byung-se stated that the South Korean government agrees to provide necessary support in the areas of research and development, information technology, health and education.

The foreign minister went on to say that  in order to strengthen bilateral ties between the two countries, the agreement for development will help raise 300 to 500 million US dollars, and measures will be taken by the South Korean government to provide facilities including bowsers to supply water for drought stricken areas.

hits._id: Registration of students to Law College postponed by another week

_source.content:
Registration of students to Law College this year has been postponed by yet another week.

Law College Principal Dr. W. D. Rodrigo told our news team that this decision was taken on the advice of the Law Education Council.

While the 'Bodu Bala Senaa' representatives met the Law College Principal on the 8th, the Principal expressed his decision on that occasion.

In coincidence with allegations made by various sections about irregularities having taken place in the 2012 Law Entrance Examination, talks cropped up in Society with regard to this.

Law College Principal Dr. W. D. Rodrigo elaborating on the subject stated as follows.

hits._id: Appropriation bill presented before parliament; VAT amendment draft bill to be presented in Oct

_source.content: The Appropriation Bill for next year was presented to parliament today.  Accordingly, the government’s total expenditure is Rs. 1819 billion. Finance Minsiter Ravi Karunanayake presented the relevant appropriation bill pertaining to the 2017 Fiscal year, and it is considered as the first budget reading. In comparison to the government expenditure of the previous budget, there is a reduction of Rs. 122 billion in the budget for next year. However, the allocation for the President has increased by Rs. 4.06 billion against the previous Rs. 2.39 billion.  The total allocation for the President for next year has been billed as Rs. 6.45 billion.  In addition, Rs. 5.76 billion has been allocated for the Mahaweli Development and Environment Ministry which is also coming under the purview of the President. Furthermore, the Ministry of National Integration and Reconciliation was allocated a sum of Rs. 1.83 billion. Meanwhile, Rs. 1.23 billion have been allocated for the Prime Minister.  In comparison to the previous year’s allocation for the Premier, an increment of Rs. 770 million can be observed this year.  In addition, National Policy and Economic Affairs Ministry which also comes under the purview of the Prime Minister, has been allocated Rs. 12.5 billion. Meanwhile, the highest appropriation has been allocated for the National Defence in the next year’s budget as well, which amounts to Rs. 284 billion.  Rs. 251 billion out of the total Defence appropriation has been billed for recurrent expenditure. The second biggest allocation has been made for the Ministry of Finance and the Finance Ministry has been allocated a sum of Rs. 242.2 billion. Provincial Council and Local Government Ministry has been allocated Rs. 214.1 billion, while Public Administration Ministry has been allocated Rs. 165.2 billion. In addition, Rs. 160.9 billion was allocated for the Health and Indigenous Medicine Ministry. Health ministry was allocated Rs. 174 billion in last budget. Meanwhile, it is significant that the allocation for the Education Ministry has been reduced by 41% in comparison to its allocations in the previous budget.  Education Ministry has been allocated only Rs. 76.9 billion in the budget for next year. In addition, Rs. 163.4 billion has been allocated for High Education and Highways Ministry.Meanwhile, the lowest allocation was made to the minister of Special Assignment Sarath Amunugama’s ministry, and the allocation amounts to Rs. 110 million. The second time budget reading by the Finance Minister will take place on the 10th of November, and the Budget is expected to be taken up for debate on the 10th of December.

hits._id: Postal voting is peaceful; says monitoring organisations #GenElecSL

Other government officials have been facilitated to cast their vote on August 5th and 6th.At the same time, officials attached to the Election Department and District Secretariats could cast their vote on August 8th.Meanwhile, those who may miss to cast their vote today can use their voting on August 8th by forwarding their individual voting card to the receiving officer of the respective district. 567 thousand 291 government officials have been qualified for postal voting this time.Meanwhile, Executive Director of Paffrel Organization Rohana Hettiarachchi said that the postal voting have been held peacefully so far.

hits._id: Trial on Economics question paper begins; Examinations commissioner appears before HRC.

_source.content: A Human Rights Commission member Dr. Prathibha Mahanama Hewa said that all parties concerned agreed to amicably settle the disputes of the controversial Economics Exam Paper of 2014.Dr. Mahanama Hewa told this to our news team after hearing the petition filed by the Lanka Teachers Association today.10 University teachers who mark Economic Exam Paper wrote to the Examination Commissioner General on 10th of August and said there were 15 errors in the Question paper this year.Based on that letter by university teachers, Lanka Teachers Association submitted a petition to the Human Rights Commission mentioning the said university dons as witnesses.The petitioner has named Education Ministry Secretary and Examination Commissioner as respondents.Accordingly Examination Commissioner W.M.N.J. Pushpakumara appeared before the Human rights Commission today.

hits._id: Video: 3 student protests in Colombo - Trade Unions on a protest march

_source.content: Several protests were staged in 3 different locations today demanding solutions to accumulated problems within the university system.The Inter University Students Federation staged a protest against cancellation of a 4-year degree course on Allied Health Science opposite the Fort Railway Station this afternoon.Students of the University of Colombo also staged a protest opposite the campus demanding an immediate solution to the lack of hostel facilities.Vehicular traffic came to a near standstill this afternoon due to the protest by University students.Meanwhile a group of students who passed the GCE A/Level in 2012 gathered near the University Grants Commission this afternoon and complained of discrimination when aggregated marks were being released. Later Higher Education Minister S.B. Dissanayake invited the students for a discussion.

hits._id: GMOA threatens to take tougher stance on SAITM

_source.content:
The strike launched by the Government Medical Officers’ Association in collaboration with several trade unions attached to health, education and other sectors will continue until tomorrow morning.
Our correspondents said that daily functions of hospitals, schools and universities were affected due to the strike.
The OPD and clinical services were the worst affected.
However, our correspondents state that emergency and essential services were not affected due to the strike.
Meanwhile, the GMOA Secretary, Dr. Haritha Aluthge said that his organization will take a critical decision next week if the Government does not take action to abolish the Malabe Private Medical College.
The General Secretary of the Ceylon Teacher Services Union, Mahinda Jayasinghe also said the Government should solve this problem.

hits._id: Government doctors say today is decisive, Minister Kiriella requests doctors view face-book

_source.content: The GMOA says that a number of decisions affecting the country are scheduled to be made at the central committee meeting to be held today.GMOA media spokesman Dr. Samantha Ananda told our news team that lengthy discussions regarding the next doctors’ strike scheduled to be held in connection with the SAITM issue would take place and a final decision would be made today.Participating at a media briefing held in Colombo yesterday GMOA assistant secretary Dr. Haritha Aluthgey elaborated on the subject as follows. Meanwhile expressing his views to media after a meeting held in Kandy yesterday, minister of Higher Education and Highways Lakshman Kiriella said that it has been observed on face book that a large percentage of the population are opposed to the strikes.

hits._id: President leaves to Russia

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena left the island this morning on an official visit to the Russian Federation at the invitation of President Vladimir Putin.
This visit marks the first official visit to Russia by a Sri Lankan leader since 1974.
This year also marks the 60th anniversary of the establishment diplomatic relations between the two countries.
During this state visit, President Sirisena is scheduled to hold bilateral discussions with Russian President Vladimir Putin tomorrow.
A review of progress made in the longstanding bilateral relationship, including the way forward to further promote trade and investment between the two countries will be discussed.
Several bilateral agreements in the areas of fisheries, tourism, cultural and education cooperation, including cooperation in the science and technology sector, are scheduled to be signed.

hits._id: SLMC challenges appeal court judgment over SAITM

_source.content:
The Sri Lanka Medical Council filed a petition today with the Supreme Court challenging the verdict by the Court of Appeal over the Malabe Private Medical School.
In its petition, the SLMC requested the Supreme Court to declare the judgment issued by the Court of Appeal on January 13 null and void.
The petition has also requested the Supreme Court to issue an interim injunction to prevent the implementation of the judgment issued by the Appeal Court.
It is stated that 6 factions including Higher Education Minister Lakshman Kiriella and the management of Malabe Private Medical School have been named as respondents.
The judgment issued by the Court Of Appeal on January 13 ordered the SLMC to register students who pass out from Malabe Private Medical School.

hits._id: Northern Education Minister hands over resignation letter

_source.content:
Northern Provincial Council Education Minister S. Kuru-kula-raasaa has handed in a letter, temporarily resigning from his ministerial post to Ilankai Tamul Arasu Katchi   lead by MP Maavai Senaadhiraajaa.
The Provincial Council Minister has said in his letter that he had  resigned from the post until an investigation was held and a final decision taken regarding corruption charges levelled against him.
A debate will be held on Wednesday this week,   at the provincial council regarding corruption charges levelled against four Northern Provincial Ministers.
Similarly while the report of the three-member committee appointed to inquire into the corruption charges levelled against the four Ministers has reached the Northern Province Chief Minister, the debate will be held regarding the content of the report.

hits._id: 70th budget to be presented in parliament today

_source.content:
Finance Minister Ravi Karunanayake says that a long term development oriented budget to fulfill the aspirations of all people will be presented to parliament today at 2.00pm.
The theme of Budget 2017 is “A budget for rapid development with benefits to all”. 
It is the 70th budget of Independence Sri Lanka and the third budget by the National Unity Government.  
The Finance Ministry has received nearly 2500 public proposals to be considered for the budget. 
Budget 2017 has focused on finding solutions to issues of several sectors in the economy including unemployment, cost of living, investment promotion, education, health and agricultural issues.
Speaking to our news team, Minister Karunanayake said that he expects to present a people’s friendly budget this time.

hits._id: UPFA election campaign in Kurunegala has collapsed; says Min AkIla #GenElecSL

_source.content: Minister of Education Akila Viraj Kariyawasam says that the UPFA election campaign in Kurunegala district has completely collapsed.The Minister stated this while speaking during a media briefing held at his party office in Kuliyapitiya this morning.Meanwhile, former MP Namal Rajapaksa stated that he was asked to appear before the FCID tomorrow.He stated this while making a statement in his Twitter profile.However, former MP Dilan Perera stated that the Election Commissioner has informed to refrain from summoning election candidates to the FCID prior to the election.He stated this while addressing a UPFA media briefing convened in Colombo today.JVP Western provincial councilor and Chairman of National Trade Union Centre K.D. Lalkantha stated that the country’s trade unions are more powerful than any other organization in the trading world.

hits._id: President to Maldives

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapaksa has decided to visit the Maldives on Wednesday.No details on the purpose or nature of his visit were immediately clear.President Rajapaksa's intention to visit the Maldives was first announced when President Abdulla Yameen Abdul Gayoom had met him in India at the sidelines of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's oath-taking ceremony in New Delhi last month.The Sri Lankan president had last visited the Maldives during former President Mohamed Nasheed’s rule in 2010.He had come then volunteering to act as a mediator between the government and the opposition to end a political deadlock.President Yameen had visited Sri Lanka in January.Sri Lanka is home to more than 10,000 Maldivians residing in the country for education, medial purposes and business.

hits._id: Health authorities warn ‘viral fever’ could spread further in South

_source.content:
The Health authorities warn that as a result of prevailing rains, there is an increased risk of viral fever which is spreading in the Southern Province, becoming further enhanced.
 
A team of experts from the Borella Medical Research Institute carried out spot checks in Kamburupitiya, Matara, and Karapitiya yesterday (May 21).
 
They will submit a complete report soon.
 
The Southern Province Health Service Director's Office said that currently more than 600 patients are being treated at Karapitiya, Matara, Elpitiya, Kamburupitiya, Tangalla and Walasmulla hospitals.
 
Meanwhile, Southern Province Education Ministry has instructed that all pre-schools be closed from today till 27th this month.
 
It has also been instructed that primary schools in Galle, Matara, Akuressa, Mulatiyana, Tangalle, and Walasmulla educational zones be closed today and tomorrow.

hits._id: SAITM: Government’s final decision this week

_source.content:
The Government’s decision regarding the Malabe private medical college (SAITM) is scheduled to be announced this week.
Participating at a function held in Colombo yesterday (22) President Maithripala Sirisena said that the final decision will be revealed this week.
Similarly, Higher Education and Highways Minister Lakshman Kiriella said in Parliament recently that action would be taken to give a solution to the SAITM problem within this week.
Meanwhile, the Government Medical Faculty Student’s Parent’s Association says that if the Government does not provide an acceptable solution to the problem regarding SAITM, 250 parents will launch a fast unto death.
The SITM Parents’ Forum and the Government Medical Faculty Student’s Parent’s Association held a joint media briefing in Colombo yesterday (22) to explain their stance.

hits._id: Accident Risk High On Southern Expressway

_source.content:
Two thousand five hundred and ninety traffic accidents have taken place on the Southern Expressway so far since its opening, Higher Education and Highways Minister Lakshman Kiriella said in Parliament yesterday (10).
He added that 20 persons have died in the accidents while 402 suffered injuries. Minister Kiriella said the government has identified certain spots on the Southern Expressway which has a high risk of accidents and would consider to find solutions. Minister Kiriella made these observations in response to a question by UNP Parliamentarian for oral answers.
The Minister further stated that the construction of the Kandy-Colombo expressway will be commenced in June this year. He also added that the government is seeking an investor for the Ruwanpura Expressway.

hits._id: Vaiko calls for LTTE ban to be lifted; wants a referendum to instate Eelam

_source.content: The MDMK has promised in its manifesto that it would lift the ban on the LTTE.According to the MDMK, the Indian Constitution when it was formed promised a federal governance structure.The party also demanded the centre to transfer back to the states the powers relating to education and the residuary powers listed in the Constitution should be fully given to the states.The party said it would work for holding of a referendum on creation of Eelam in Sri Lanka for Lankan Tamils.The party said it would ban death penalty.The MDMK also promised to work to force India to take severe action against Sri Lanka over the fishermens issue and also retrieve Katchatheevu -- an islet in Palk Strait -- from Sri Lanka.

hits._id: Inform CID regarding all examination disruptions - President instructs Minister

_source.content:
Education Minister Bandula Gunawardana said that he had received instructions from the President, to hand over to the CID all information about examination sabotage and publicity stunts, with regard to such incidents.
 
When the Minister met the President on Thursday, he has told the Minister that conducting investigation by the CID, would be more appropriate.
 
Accordingly, the Minister has already handed over to the CID all available information for further action.
 
The Minister said that certain interested parties used SMS, telephone and email services, to carry out a false campaign about examinations.
 
He told our news team, that similar false information is being circulated about the ongoing Advanced Level examination as well, and investigations are now being held to trap the miscreants.

hits._id: GMOA strike disrupts functions at Western Province hospitals

The strike launched by the GMAO in protest of SAITM has been extended for an additional 24 hours.

hits._id: Young Journos' Association Condemns Minister Kiriella's Act

_source.content:
Young Journalists’ Association (YJA) issued a statement condemning the incident of Minister of Higher Education and Highways Lakshman Kiriella using offensive language towards journalist.

hits._id: Bail decision for the couple remanded for Kotakethana Mother and daughter's murder - postponed to July 3rd

_source.content: The Colombo High Court decided to hear the bail application for the two suspects of Kotaketana double murder case on July 3rd.Lokugam Hevage Darshana alias Raju and his wife Rasika Chandani were charged for the murder of 52-year old Nayana Nilmini and her 18-year old daughter Kavindya Chathurangi on January 31st 2012.When the case was taken before Colombo High Court Judge Sarojani Kusala Weerawardana, the suspects’ lawyers informed the court that the two suspects have already spent over 3 years in remand prison.The lawyers also said that education of the children of the two suspects have been affected after they were remanded.However, after the state counsel objected granting bail for the suspects the Judge postponed granting bail for the suspects.

hits._id: Injustice : Little girl suspended from school citing HIV concerns (Photos)

_source.content:
Little girl suspended citing HIV concerns”A grade-5 schoolgirl and two women staged a sit-in protest in front of the Zonal Education Director's Office in Gampaha after the school authorities evicted the little girl from the school.
 
The mother of the girl is an HIV positive and the little girl is attending school while being under the care of her mother's younger sister.
 
The mother of the girl and her sister took part in the sit-in protest.
 
They were wearing face masks and urged the authorities to provide a solution to the little girl, who is to sit for the Grade-5 scholarship examination this year.
 
Our correspondent said that the little girl is a hardworking girl and she obtains highest marks in the school examination becoming first in the class regularly. 
 
The daughter has been suspended from Gampaha- Ganemulla Kudabollatha Sri Sumangala Vidyalaya for a second time on 20th of March.
 
The mother went on to state that her daughter was to sit the Grade 5 scholarship examination this year and that officials responsible have failed to provide a solution with regard to the matter.
 
Previously, the student was expelled from the school on the claims that the mother was HIV positive.
 
However, the Sri Lanka Human Rights Commission made the way for the student to be granted re-entry to the school on several conditions that were agreed on by the principal and officials.
 
Minister of Education, Akila Viraj Kariyawasam had previously stated that the student studying in the primary school, speculated of being HIV positive, would not be treated unjustly.
 
However, medical tests have proven that the girl has not contacted the disease.
 
Hiru news reported on this story when the initial incident took place on 17th of March last year.

hits._id: Preschools in Matara to be closed for one more week

_source.content:
Matara District Preschool Association says that it has decided to extend the closure of the Matara District preschools by five days till 10th of this month due to the spread of the viral fever in the Southern Province.
Earlier the Southern Province Education Ministry had decided to close down the Southern Province pre-schools till yesterday.
However, at a media briefing yesterday, Matara District preschool Association Secretary Prince Thamaraa Manoj said that as a precautionary measure it decided to extend the period of closure of preschools in the Matara District by another five days.
According to the Sri Lanka Medical Research Institute, it is revealed that this disease condition has occurred due to the spread of Influenza A virus.
By now 12 children in the Southern Province have succumbed to this viral fever.

hits._id: War commemorations held in North

_source.content:
A memorial statue for the Tamil people who died in the war was declared open with the participation of Northern Chief Minister, C. V. Wigneshwaran in the coastal area of Mullivaikkal in Mullaitivu this morning (May 18).
 
A group of Northern Provincial Councillors and another group of students from Jaffna University arrived in a motorcade to Mullivaikal to participate in the event.
 
Students of the Jaffna University also organized a commemoration for the Tamil people who died in the conflict.
 
It is also reported that many schools in the North flew the provincial flag at half-mast today.
 
Earlier, Northern Provincial Education Minister asked school administration to do so.
 
However, Minister of Law and Order Ranjith Madduma Bandara said that no legal permission has been given to hold commemorations of the war dead.

hits._id: Chinese Envoy Visits North, Offers Assistance For Development

_source.content:
Visiting Chinese Ambassador Yi Xianliang assured in Jaffna yesterday that China will extend its fullest support to develop the former war torn areas as two governments’ shares a cordial relationship.
Ambassador Xianliang met senior higher officials in the region including Governor Reginald Cooray and Chief Minister C.V.Wigneswaran.
The Chinese Ambassador had told the Governor that China and Sri Lanka enjoy strong historical ties and that the relationship must be taken forward.
The Ambassador also noted that the Chinese Embassy in Colombo is keen to offer assistance to boost the education levels of children in the North.
He also said that China will consider offering scholarships to children in the North.
China has invested heavily in Sri Lanka, particularly to develop the road network and also funded the construction of a port and international airport.

hits._id: Students can go to school in casual clothing

_source.content:
The Education Ministry says that if as a result of the island’s inclement weather school uniforms have been destroyed, permission has been granted for school children to attend school dressed in alternate appropriate clothing.   
Minister in charge Akila Viraj Kariyawasam told our news team that information had been received to the effect that consequent to the heavy rain that persisted throughout the past several days school children’s uniforms had been destroyed. 
In coincidence with the downpour over the past few days all schools were closed last Friday.
However Minister Kariyawasam said that educational activities will be resumed today as usual.
However while it has been decided to indefinitely close down 52 schools in the Sabaragamuwa Province, schools in the Kolonnawa and Kaduwela areas will remain closed today and tomorrow.

hits._id: Teachers Association Complains To HRC Against Revised Cut-Off Marks Of Year 5 Scholarship

_source.content:
The Ceylon teachers union handed in a complaint to the Human Rights Commission with regard to the amendment made to the grade 5 scholarship exam cut off mark applicable to 8 Colombo schools.
Secretary of the Union Joseph Stalin noted that this adjustment is an unjust move as it will be disadvantageous for students in the respective schools.
The Department of Education announced yesterday that the cut off mark will be reduced by one mark for students gaining admission to Royal College in Colombo, Ananda, Nalanda, D.S Senanayake, Isipathana, Thurstan, Mahanama and Pannipitiya Dharmpala College’s respectively.
The reason for this amendment came about following the addition of a grade 6 class at Royal College Colombo.
However, the Secretary of the Ceylon Teachers' Union Joseph Starling noted that there’s no statistical base for such a decrease.

hits._id: Minister in charge of police must resign; says JVP

hits._id: Decisions will not be taken merely to protect the government; says President-Video

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapaksa stressed that the government has no necessity to hide the development process of the country.He said the government has perfectly put forward the development process to the country.While addressing the releasing ceremony of 2013 Annual Report of the Ministry of Finance in Colombo today, President stated that the government has made considerable changes in education and will not curtail free education.The President also emphasized that decisions are not taken with mere intention of protecting the government or power.He further stated that there have been protests against building the Norochcholai and Upper Kotmale Power plants, but the government acted with no consideration to retain the votes or safeguard the government.Speaking further at the ceremony the President asked the Ministerial Secretaries not to issue circulars arbitrarily and create inconveniences to the people.

hits._id: PM urges supermarkets to introduce 'Fair Price Shops'

_source.content:
It was decided at a meeting chaired by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesing to establish 'Fair Price Shops' with the support of private sector in order to control the rising Cost of Living during the festive season.
 
Through those shops, a 'Budget Pack' will be sold to the consumers for a concessionary price.
 
The 'Budget Pack' will include rice, dhal, sugar, sprats, onions, potatoes and canned fish.
 
The mechanism will be introduced to supermarket chains and Lak Sathosa outlets.
 
Meanwhile, at another meeting, Prime Minister urged the university authorities to concentrate on improving the quality of higher education instead of prioritizing constructing buildings at universities.
 
The meeting was attended by Vice Chancellors of universities.
 
The PM also said steps should be taken to get rid of ragging in universities.

hits._id: Inter university students’ protest march banned

_source.content:
Colombo Chief Magistrate Laal Ranasinghe Bandara has issued an injunction order preventing the protest march that was scheduled to be staged by the Inter-university students’ federation and the Medical Faculty  steering committee in several locations around Colombo today and tomorrow.
The Chief Magistrate had issued the restraining order after considering   the information Cinnamon Garden Police had provided stating that there were preparations for staging agitations and protest marches in a manner that would impede public peace and obstruct people’s daily activities.
The inter-university federation and the medical students’ steering committee were due to launch protest marches over several educational issues including abolishing Malabe Private Medical College, which was intended to be staged infront of Colombo Ward Place,  the national hospital, the eye hospital and the Higher Education Ministry.

hits._id: Honorary doctorate to PM from Deakin University

_source.content:
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe was awarded an honorary doctorate from Australia's Deakin University at its autumn graduation held today in Geelong, Australia.
Prime Minister Wickremesinghe was recognized for significant contributions in reforms in economy, education and human rights in Sri Lanka.
Introducing the Prime Minister , Vice Chancellor and President of Deakin University Professor Jane den Hollander said that  the Prime Minister’s  significant achievements include, restoring full-time electricity, rejuvenating the ailing economy, breaking down the many ethnic barriers in the country, and galvanizing the goodwill and the financial support of the international community for Sri Lanka.
Prime Minister Wickremesinghe will also meet with the governor of Victoria Linda Dessau and then head to Canberra for a reception with Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull to commemorate 70 years of Australian-Sri Lankan diplomatic relations.

hits._id: University Functions Continue To Be Crippled

_source.content:
Universities have been crippled today (28) with the ongoing the strike being staged by non-academic workers. The strike was launched yesterday on 7 demands including a systematic pension scheme.
University services including library and general administration did not function yesterday due to the strike.

Meanwhile Sabaragamuwa University suspended study programs of all faculties due to the strike.  
Vice Chancellor of Peradeniya University Professor. Upul Dissanayake also said that the university was affected by the strike.

hits._id: Dr. Indrajith Coomaraswamy to Head CBSL from Monday

_source.content:
President Maithreepala Sirisena announced that Dr. Indrajith Coomaraswamy will be appointed as the Governor of Central Bank on coming Monday, the 4th of July.
Dr. Indrajith Coomaraswami who was born in 1950, pursued his education at Colombo Royal College and Harrow College in England  is a prominent Sri Lankan economist who was the former Director Economic Affairs at the Commonwealth Secretariat from 1990 to 2008.
In addition, Dr. Coomaraswami holds a first class honours degree from the Cambridge University and obtained his PhD from the Sussex University.
After joining the Central Bank in the year 1973, he served as an officer attached to the sections of economic research, statistics and Bank Supervision until 1989.
Dr. Indrajith Coomaraswami also served in the Ministry of Finance and Planning from 1981 to 1989.

hits._id: Autism: the silence that needs to be heard

_source.content:
Autism is a subject rarely spoken of in Sri Lanka, even though state data shows that one per cent of the children born annually are vulnerable for Autism Spectrum Disorder. This number translate into approximately 3, 750.
It is amidst this that the World Autism Awareness Day fell on April 02, where the subject emerged for a brief period as the Ministry of Education initiated several programs to raise awareness among the public.
The government will take steps to establish health clinics, centers to train autistic children in all districts.

The Disaster Management Center urges the people who are living in low-lying areas of Nilwala, Kalu, Gin, Kelani rivers and Aththanagalu and Maa Oya to be vigilant for possible floods.
 
Meanwhile, the death toll as a result of the inclement weather has risen to 6.
 
Four persons including a Buddhist nun died from being struck by lightning in separate incidents in Horana, Welikanda.
 
Another person died as a soil mound collapsed on their house at Undugoda in Bulathkohupitiya last night.
 
In Monaragala, a woman died after a tree branch fell on her in Badalkumubura.
 
The Disaster management Center has requested that the public take precautionary measures during lightning and storms.
 
Additionally, the center has requested the public to refrain from visiting flood-affected areas on sight-seeing.
 
Our correspondents reported that traffic has been affected in many areas due flooding.
 
Meanwhile, Education Minister, Akila Viraj Kariyawasam said that authority has been vested in zonal education officers, including school principals to decide whether schools should be closed or not, due to the inclement weather conditions.
 
It was announced that schools in Ratnapura, Nivitigala and Dehiovita educational zones in the Sabaragamuwa Province would remain closed today and tomorrow.
 
 In addition, several schools in Akuressa, Panadugama, and Athuraliye in Matara district were also closed.
 
The Department of Meteorology warned that the impact of ongoing inclement weather could increase if the current low-pressure zone in the Bay of Bengal develops into a depression as it reaches the island.
 
The Department said, however, in the next 24 hour period 100 to 150 millimeters of rain is predicted for the Western, Sabaragamuwa, North-Western, Central, Uva provinces and the districts of Galle and Matara.
 
By 8.30 this morning, 353.8 millimeters of rain was reported in Anamaduwa, Puttalam.
 
The NBRO has issued landslide warning for Galle, Kalutara, Ratnapura, Nuwara Eliya and Kegalle districts and it has been further extended for another 24 hours.
 
A “Red alert” has been issued for Palinda Nuwara Divisional Secretariat for landslides.
 
The evacuation of residents in areas prone to landslides has begun.

hits._id: Clear Change of Ministerial Subjects

_source.content:
The political sources stated that subjects of several former ministers have been changed in allocating ministry portfolios of the new government.
Accordingly, it is reported that new faces have been selected to run the subjects of Law and Order, Power and Energy, Media, Home Affairs, Land and Highways.
The same sources disclosed that several new ministries have been added to the Cabinet of the new government.
The Cabinet of the new government is scheduled to be sworn in on September 2nd. 
MP elect Mahinda Amaraweera said that 30 ministries have been allocated for the UNP while 15 ministries have been billed for the SLFP.
Accordingly, SLFP ministry slots would include Higher Education, Agriculture, Irrigation, Petroleum, Samurdhi and Fisheries.
The sources also stated that former Finance Minister Ravi Karunanayake would receive the same ministry but Banking and financial service sector have been removed from the Finance Ministry and brought under the purview of another ministry.
A new ministry under the name of Urban Development and Megapolis has been set up and MP elect Patali Champika Ranawaka is to be picked to run that new ministry.
Ministries of Housing and Construction, Education, Ports and Shipping as well as Health will be offered to the MPs Sajith Premadasa, Akila Viraj Kariyawasam, Arjuna Ranatunga and Rajitha Senaratne respectively.
In addition, sources have revealed that former Minister Palani Digambaram will be sworn in again as the Minister of Estate Infrastructure.
It is also reported that M.K.D.S. Gunawardena will be sworn in as the Minister of Buddha Sasana, Gayantha Karunaratne as Minister of Plantation Industries, John Amaratunga as Minister of Power and Lakshman Kiriella as Minister of Highways will be sworn in respectively.
In addition, political sources revealed that MPs Harin Fernando and Vajira Abeywardena who were re-elected to Parliament and MP S.B. Nawinna who joined the UNP prior to the General Election will be offered cabinet ministerial portfolios.

hits._id: Inter University Students Federation to Colombo in a protest march

_source.content: The Inter University Students Federation was engaged in a protest march today against the police attack on HNDA students and on several other demands including the banning of private universities.The protest march which commenced from the Sri Jayewardenepura University was concluded in front of the Higher Education Ministry on Ward Place Colombo this afternoon.Heavy traffic was reported on the High Level road due to the student protest.Members of the IUSF of several universities and the members of the HNDA collective had joined the march. At the same time, Inter University Bhikku Students Federation, Medial College Students activists and several other students’ organizations had also joined the march.Our correspondents stated that almost all roads around Colombo Town Hall have been blocked as protesting students were staying on the road in front of the University grants Commission.Police received two injunctions against the student march today, but students continued their march saying that they did not receive any court order in writing.Our correspondents stated that around 40 policemen were positioned around the University Grants Commission.Meanwhile two petitions filed by the Jathika Balaya and Inter University Student Federation were taken for hearing before the Human Rights Commission today.Director of the Investigation and inspection Unit, Sithara Thambiliyagoda told our news team that the petition would be taken again on next Thursday.Meanwhile Jathika Balaya member and leader of Nava Hela Urumaya, Sarath Manamendra said that police have become helpless before this incident.Meanwhile the petition filed by the students with the Police Commission was also taken for hearing today. During the hearing, the Police Commission has recorded a statement from the convener of the HNDA collective Dhammika Ruwan Kumarage.At the same time, Higher Education and Highways Minister has submitted a Cabinet paper seeking approval to empower a previous Circular which had granted degree status to the HNDA course.Ministry Secretary D.C. Dissanayake told our news team that the Cabinet would draw its attention to this matter during the next Cabinet meeting.

hits._id: COPE investigates Central Expressway tender

_source.content:
The Parliamentary Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) has decided to prepare a special report on the construction of the Central Expressway.
The Auditor General Gamini Wijesinghe told our news team that this special investigation will probe the alleged misappropriation being committed in offering tenders to build the expressway.
The auditing process has already begun and, soon after the first phase is complete, the report will be submitted to the Parliament, he added.
In addition, a special report prepared by the COPE relating to the construction of the expressway between Matara and Hambantota has already been submitted to the Parliament.
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe recently also made a special statement in Parliament on the procedures adopted in awarding contracts in the Central Expressway.
On 21st of September, Minister Higher Education and Highways, Lakshman Kiriella stated that no corruption has been committed in offering tenders to build the Central Expressway.

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena says that the government hopes to educate school students regarding the country's common laws.
The President expressed these views joining the Polonnaruwa district summit of the “Protect Children” national programme at the Polonnaruwa Royal College yesterday (10).

hits._id: Finance Minister says he will be presenting a development oriented budget today

_source.content:
Finance Minister Ravi Karunanayake says that a long term development oriented budget to fulfill the aspirations of all people will be presented to parliament today at 2pm.
The theme of Budget 2017 is “A budget for rapid development with benefits to all”.

hits._id: A judge reveals the reality with regard to child abuse

_source.content: Justice Khemaa Swarnaa-dhipathi said that the majority of the 25 court cases recently instituted at the Anuradhapura special High Court were child abuses committed by fathers, fathers’ younger brothers and mothers’ brothers.On this occasion the Justice said that child abuses are reported more from rural areas than from urban areas.Justice Khemaa Swarnaa-dhipathi points out that while the risk of particularly children facing such situations is more in the dry zone, parents’ ignorance and child labour cause such abuse.Underage marriage, unplanned childbirth and poverty too are among the causes of child sexual abuse. Justice Khemaa Swarnaa-dhipathi said that in most cases such children are subjected to such situations more than once.The Justice pointed out further that the absence of sexual education to children is also a reason for the increase in child abuse incidents.A special High Court was set up at the Anuradhapura Court Complex one and a half years ago for considering cases connected with child abuse incidences and terrorist activities.

hits._id: Teachers Unions charge that lunch at some schools has stopped

_source.content:
Teachers Unions allege that the lunch that is provided free of charge by the government to Rural schools has stopped in certain areas.
 
The Lanka Teachers Union stated that the reason for this was the failure to make payments to those providing the daily meals to schools.
 
Schools housing students from low income earning families as well as schools with a higher percentage of students suffering from mal nutrition are provided a noon meal.
 
However, General Secretary of the Lanka Teachers Union Joseph Starlin stated that the failure to make payments to suppliers has led to a halt in supplying the noon meal to students.
 
However, when we inquired from the Education Services Ministry a spokesperson stated that funds required to make payments for the month of July was not received from the Treasury as yet.
 
The Ministry also stated that making payments has not been suspended and no soon as funds are received the due payments will be settled.

hits._id: Motion ruling enrolment of 5, 069 University students to be called up tomorrow

_source.content:
The Supreme Court today postponed till tomorrow the hearing of the petition filed by the University Grants Commission stating that practical issues were being experienced when absorbing a further 5, 609 students to the countries university system for the academic years 2011 & 2012.

According to a Supreme Court ruling issued on the 12th of September 2012, each respective institute of Higher Education was instructed to conduct the required practical and fitness tests required by students.

The names of students who were successful in these tests were in turn received by the University Grants Commission.

In return the University Grants Commissions informed court that it was unable to enrol the stipulated number of students from certain districts since students who had obtained the required marks for enrolment were scarce.

The Supreme Courts ruling to enrol a further 5, 609 students came as it considered several petitions which were filed by several students who challenged the 2011 Advanced Level Examination results.

hits._id: Sri Lanka welcomes Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop

_source.content:
Australia's Foreign Affairs Minister Julie Bishop arrived in sri lanka yesterday on a two-day official visit.
Welcoming the Australian Minister her Sri Lankan counterpart, Minister Ravi Karunanayake said the visit is significant, since it coincides with the 70th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between Sri Lanka and Australia.
The two Foreign Ministers held discussions on how to further enhance the bilateral cooperation in areas of mutual interest, which included economic partnership, development cooperation, combating people smuggling, education and skill development, tourism, reconciliation and the role by Overseas Sri Lankans in the development of Sri Lanka.
He said this year the diplomatic relations between Sri Lanka and Australia have generated a new momentum in the longstanding relations with a series of recent high level visits undertaken by the President and the Prime Minister.
Foreign Minister Julie Bishop will pay courtesy calls on President Maithripala Sirisena and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe today.

hits._id: A GMOA doctor among the 6 doctors accused of the Kidney Racket

_source.content: The GMOA for the first time revealed that a GMOA doctor is among the 6 doctors accused of the Kidney Racket.Secretary of the GMOA, Dr Nalin De Silva made this revelation during a media briefing held in Colombo today.Sri Lanka has launched an investigation into allegations that a group of surgeons ran a racket trading human kidneys, two days after the authorities banned all kidney transplant surgery for foreigners.The health ministry has appointed a committee of five experts to run the investigation.Allegations of the racket first surfaced in Indian media.Most of the alleged recipients of the illegally traded kidneys were Indian nationals.According to the reports, around 60 people sold their kidneys for transplants at four hospitals in Colombo since 2012.The Indian police had named at least six Sri Lankan doctors involved in the alleged illegal transplants.Meanwhile, state Minister of Education V Radakrishnan states that estate workers are victims of the Kidney Racket.

hits._id: 4 students admitted to hospital following a clash

_source.content:
4 students have been admitted to the Padaviya hospital as a result of a clash that occurred between two groups of students who took part in a seminar at the Padaviya Mahasen Vidyalaya.
 
The seminar was organized by the North Central Education Department for students who are sitting for the ordinary level exam this year.
 
Apart from the students of the Padaviya Mahasen Vidyalaya, students from the Padaviya Buddangala Maha Vidyalaya and Parakramapura Maha Vidyalaya also took part in this seminar.
 
The clash took place as a result of an argument that took place regarding insufficient seating at the seminar.
 
The police stated that 3 of the students who were admitted to hospital were from the Padaviya Buddangala Maha Vidyalaya and the other student was from Padaviya Mahasen Vidyalaya.
 
Parents of the students who were attacked stated that their children were attacked utilizing sharp implements.
 
Upon inquiry by our news team, a police spokesperson stated that an investigation has been initiated regarding the incident.

hits._id: University non-academic staff suspend strike

_source.content:
The university non-academic staff have decided to suspend their strike action which affected the functions of the state universities for more than a month.
 
The strike was launched citing six demands including a monthly allowance.
 
Examinations at all the state universities were postponed and all other day-to-day activities have affected.
 
As a result university student unions also staged protests, demanding that the universities be re-opened after solving the issues of non-academic staff.
 
University non-academic employees’ Trade Unions’ Joint Committee and Higher Education Minister Kabir Hashim held a discussion yesterday (Apr. 02).
 
Union co-chairman Edward Malwatthage said they are planning to resume work from tomorrow.Meanwhile, the airport staff who staged a demonstration at the BIA premises yesterday say if they do not get a favourable response to their demands by 11 am today, the employees will launch a strike action.The employees of Mattala and Ratmalana airports have said that they would also join the strike action.

hits._id: President to visit Russia tomorrow

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena will undertake an official visit to the Russian Federation tomorrow at the invitation of President Vladimir Putin.
The upcoming visit will be the first official visit to Russia by a Sri Lankan leader since 1974.
The visit takes place as both countries celebrate the 60th anniversary of the establishment diplomatic relations.
During the visit, President Sirisena is scheduled to hold a bilateral meeting with his counterpart on 23rdMarch.
The official discussions are expected to review progress made in the longstanding bilateral relationship, including the way forward to further promote trade and investment between the two countries. 
Several bilateral agreements in several areas are scheduled to be signed. These areas include fisheries, tourism, cultural and education cooperation, including cooperation in the science and technology sector,
In order to actively promote trade and business links between the two countries, a Sri Lanka-Russia Business Forum will be held in Moscow, and Sri Lanka will be represented by a delegation of the Sri Lanka –Russia Business Council.

hits._id: Commonwealth Lawyers Association passes a resolution against Sri lanka.

_source.content:
The Commonwealth Lawyers Association yesterday, passed a resolution on Sri Lanka calling for the island to be suspended from the commonwealth over allegations of serious and persistent violations of the Commonwealth fundamental values.
 
The resolution jointly submitted by the Commonwealth Lawyers Association, the Commonwealth Legal Education Association and the Commonwealth Magistrates’ and Judges’ Association at a special plenary session during the Commonwealth Law Conference in South Africa.
 
They also urge members of the Commonwealth to reconsider the holding of the next Heads of Government Meeting in Sri Lanka as to do so will tarnish the reputation of the Commonwealth.
 
It also calls upon the Members of the Commonwealth, through the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group, to place Sri Lanka on the agenda of its next meeting on 26th April 2013.
 
When asked to comment on this, Secretary of the Ministry of External Affairs Karunatilake Amunugama said that the government would not concern much on such a resolution as far as it has no any diplomatic accredit-tation.

hits._id: Uva Chief Minister to take disciplinary action against Principal

_source.content:

Principal of the Badulla Tamil Girls' School R. Bawani explaining the issue to UNP Parliamentarian Wadivel Suresh said that she had to kneel down before the Chief Minister at his residence.
 
The incident had happened on the 3rd of this month and the Principal in question said that the Uva Province Education Secretary had also influenced her.
 
She said that an individual contesting the forthcoming election had presented a letter signed by the private secretary of the Chief Minister requesting a student to be enrolled to the school.
 
However, since the maximum number of students had been enrolled, she had refused the request.
 
Later the Principal was called to the Chief Minister’s residence and scolded her.
 
She said thereafter she was forced to kneel down and apologize.

hits._id: U.S. Govt. Trains Lankan Officials on Counter Proliferation of WMD

_source.content:
The United States Government recently concluded a five-day workshop in for members of the Sri Lankan Ports Authority and Customs, Police, Navy, and Coast Guard to provide training on eliminating the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD).
Led by U.S. military experts from the International Counter proliferation Program, the workshop covered themes such as border security, technology, and threat assessment, the US Embassy in Colombo said in a statement today.
The program builds upon a strengthening US -Sri Lankan partnership that includes enhanced cooperation in security in the Indian Ocean Region.
Through the ICP Program, Defense Threat Reduction Agency of the US Department of Defense has provided training and detection equipment to over 10,000 international participants.
The agency currently provide education on countering weapons of mass destruction in more than 30 nations around the world, engaging police, border officials, investigators and national security executives who determine WMD response on and within their borders.

hits._id: Profit of Sri Lankan Airlines to be Distributed Amongst People Following Its Success

_source.content:
Prime minister Ranil Wickramasinghe emphasizes that following the revival of Sri Lankan airlines through the amalgamation with a private entity, the profit obtained would be provided to the public.
Prime Minister had informed the officers of the airlines that following the revival, the company could engage in social service as well.
The profit obtained is to be utilized for education, health and for the provision of housing to low income families.
In order to attract interest and potential investors, the debt of 461 billion rupees has been taken over by the treasury.
Four previously ordered A350 aircrafts have also been cancelled.
The government believes that selling shares of 40% to a foreign company would mediate the debt crisis.
Prime minister informed the officials of Sri Lankan airlines yesterday that the government does not want to entertain the concept of a white elephant; letting money go to waste, by continuing to facilitate the airlines.

Indian External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj says that the Central government has initiated a program in collaboration with state governments to solve the Indi Sri Lanka fishing dispute.

hits._id: Special Unit to supervise Ministries allocated with funds over Rs. 100 billion; Separate officer appointed for the task

_source.content: The government has decided to establish a Financial Management Unit to manage finances of Ministries that receive financial allocations worth over Rs. 100 billion.Finance Minister Ravi Karunanayake told our news team that the unit will be established under the purview of the Finance Ministry.In addition, he noted that a special officer will be appointed to supervise the tasks.Accordingly the Unit will be established to manage the finances of several ministries including Defence, Education, Health and Highways.The Financial Management Unit is due to produce a report within a given period of time, concerning the manner in which the funds allocated by the Budget are spent.It has also been proposed to appoint separate officers for individual ministries to prepare the relevant reports.Finance Minister Ravi Karunanayake noted that based on these reports, measures would be taken to curtail additional expenses, and decide upon sections requiring further funds.The relevant cabinet paper would be presented by the Finance Minister to the cabinet in due course.

hits._id: Prez meets Dr. Coomaraswamy

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena has met Dr. Indrajit Coomaraswamy today.
The President’s media division stated that the meeting took place at President’s official residence.
The decision to appoint Dr. Coomaraswamy as the Governor of Central Bank was taken following a meeting held between the President and the Prime Minister.  
Accordingly, he will be appointed the new Governor of Central Bank on Monday the 4th of July.
Dr. Coomaraswamy who was born in 1950, pursued his education at Colombo Royal College and Harrow College in England.
He holds a first class honours degree from the Cambridge University and obtained his PhD from the Sussex University.
After joining the Central Bank in the year 1973, he served as an officer attached to the sections of economic research, statistics and Bank Supervision until 1989.
He also served in the Ministry of Finance and Planning from 1981 to 1989.
Later he served as the Director of Economic Affairs at the Commonwealth Secretariat from 1990 to 2008.

_source.content:
The passing away of veteran musician Pandith W.D. Amaradeva saddened not just his fans in Sri Lanka but the world too.
Honorary Lecturer in Education in University of Birmingham, England, Christopher Robertson who has worked in Sri Lanka, is one such person. He shared his cherished memories of late Pandith Amaradeva with Hiru News.  
Mr. Robertson has worked with the UK based organisation Voluntary Service Overseas, at the Prithipura Communites 'project' to support the development of education, independent living and employment opportunities for disabled children and young people in Sri Lanka.
During his stay here, he has worked in Asokapura, a rural village in Kegalle district, which could be reached only on foot. In 1977 “an uphill walk of a few miles from the local hamlet of Kehelpannala”, he said.
Mr. Robertson had wanted to run a rural music event at Asokapura. This was for the disabled children and young people living there, but also local farmers and villagers.
“I knew and loved Pandith Amaradeva's music from the radio and decided to contact him directly in Colombo to ask if he might consider playing a concert at Asokapura,” he said adding, “To my amazement, he agreed, and said that he would travel to the community on the agreed date.”
After the event was arranged Pandith Amaradeva has arrived for the concert with a band.
Mr. Robertson remembered that the walk to Asokapura was tiring for late Pandith Amaradeva.
“However, after taking some refreshment, he and his fellow musicians were ready to perform. It was late in day and close to sunset, but with hastily constructed lighting in place and rudimentary amplification we were ready to go,” he writes.   “The concert lasted for a couple of hours and I shall never forget Pandit's wonderful rendition of Pawena nil walawa, as it floated underneth a starry sky and across the valley below. I shall never forget it, and I am sure the concert remained in the hearts of the local community for years to come.”
Mr. Robertson said these were “wonderful memories, of a wonderful musician and man of ordinary people”.

hits._id: JASI PASSES AWAY

_source.content: Mr Jayasingam who until recently served as chairman of EB Creasy and the Lankem group of companies, passed away after a brief illness.Jayasingam, “Jasi” the eldest son of the late Professor Nadaraser, Senior lecturer and Reader in Mathematics at the University of Ceylon, had his education at Royal College and after his secondary schooling completed the B.Com Degree from the university of London.On completion of his tertiary education in 1952, Jasi joined the prestigious trading firm of Harrisons & Crossfield Ltd as an Accountant. British Trading and Agency houses which were manned by Expatriate staff had commenced recruiting Sri Lankan executives, and Jasi was in the first batch at Harrisons, the others being Douglas Fonseka, Satchi Canagasabey and John Hitchcock. His career flourished at Harrisons and he was responsible for the Import and Export business carried out by the firm.In 1956 significant social changes followed in the country. This was a period of concerted Union activities and labour unrest.  The Trincomalee Tea Administration Board was formed to divert Tea exports through Trincomalee, thus avoiding the strife torn Colombo harbour. Jasi was one of the senior executives seconded by the export firm to run this operation in Trinco. When British expatriates in Colombo and in the Plantations started leaving the island, Jayasingam, had by then proved his mettle and was appointed the Chief Accountant, being one of the top three positions in running the Company.The next major change in his career was in 1975, when companies registered outside Sri Lanka had to register themselves with the Registrar of Companies in Colombo. Harrisons & Crossfields complied by registering their Colombo based operations and assets in a wholly owned subsidiary under the name of Harrisons Colombo Ltd. Jasi was a founder director of this Board and also its first Joint Managing Director. Soon Jayasingam assumed the position of Chairman of both Harrisons Colombo Ltd. and Harrisons Lister Colombo Ltd. He continued in this position until 1990 when he retired from Harrisons when Harrisons & Crossfields in London divested themselves of the shares in the local Company.On retirement he was invited to join the Boards of EB Creasy and Lankem Ceylon and several other Companies of the Fort Land Group. The privatization of Plantations saw him spearheading the diversification of the Group into Plantation Management.
